text:
We love this recipe and I keep finding new ways to modify it (I feel I have to, since I make it at LEAST once a week)This is how we like it: I use celery seed rather than celery salt and usually have parmesan-romano cheese blend on hand so I use that. I also add 1/2 tsp. paprika, 1/4 tsp. garlic powder and 1/4 tsp. crushed red pepper flakes.  I don't add any lemon juice anymore (I used to just reduce it by half) but now use low-fat mayo that I find to be quite tangy.  I also double the amount of pepper and add about 1/2 c. of bread crumbs to the cheese mixture, which creates a nice texture and keeps the topping in place. Seasoning the fish with a bit of Old Bay seasoning, as others have done, really adds to the flavor as well. Thank you for helping us eat fish on a regular basis, Phoebe!

text:
I made some changes to this recipe to lower some of the fat content but I still think it was delicious and deserved five stars.  Instead of using regular mayo and butter, I substituted fat free mayo and light butter.  I also sprayed the fillets with olive oil cooking spray before placing them under the broiler.  Since tilapia cooks quickly, I didn't turn them at all.  I let them cook 3 or 4 minutes (oven rack on second slot from the top), added the cheese mixture, and removed them when the cheese started to brown.

text:
I've made this several times and this is absolutely the easiest and best tilapia, or any fish, dish I have ever made. Everyone I make it for wants the recipe.  I do line a broiler pan with foil and spray the foil with cooking spray.  The only other thing I do differently is to sprinkle the fish with Old Bay Seasoning before putting under the broiler for the first time and then again before topping with the parmesan mix while it is out of the oven.  I also make sure that I start with the side of the fish that has the dark vein running through the center facing up starting out then it should end up on the bottom when finished.  Low fat mayo makes it even more healthy than it already is without making a big difference.  I've found it best to follow the cooking time closely. It's quick. It's tasty. Try it!

Only thing I did differently was to add 1/4 tsp garlic powder (because we love garlic) and 1/4 tsp paprika.  The paprika really gave it a nice flavor and added a wonderful color to the cheese sauce.  We will definitely be making this often.

text:
I scaled this recipe in half and went with some of the suggestions of reviewer, Shannon:) (click on "most helpful" and you'll see her review).  I've only had tilapia once and wasn't that impressed with that fresh-water, farmed fish, so I went with rockfish (aka: red snapper in warmer waters; rockfish in colder northern waters).  I added to the parmesan mixture:  some garlic powder, paprika, a touch of cayenne pepper & some panko bread crumbs.  This cheese mixture is really what makes the dish; it was excellent and I liked the way the bread crumbs/cheese browned lightly under the broiler.  I only had to broil the fish 2 minutes on each side, plus 2 minutes with the cheese mixture.  Served with steamed broccoli.  Talk about an easy, quick-prep meal!  Thanks, Phoebe!

text:
I was really desperate for something to do with some recently defrosted tilapia fillets and spotted this recipe and it looked interesting.

My husband loved it.  Loved the texture, the zing of the parmesan and spice was just perfect.  Will definitely make again for family & friends.  Only issue was I made the spread and put it in the fridge for 1/2 hr. early and it melted way too fast in the broiler.  Lost 1/2 the topping.  My error.  Don't recommend chilling spread 1st.

text:
Have made this on several occasions trying to find the right balance of cheese mixture to fish.  The first time I made the recipe exactly as stated (as a courteous nod to the submitter) and it swam in butter so I rated this at three stars (wonderful but loaded with calories).  The second time, I reduced the butter again to an 1/8 cup and it was still overpowered by the butter, so try, try again to one tablespoon of butter for the perfect mixture.  Wonderful flavor!!!

text:
We're fish lovers, so maybe that's what influenced our opinion of this dish. The sauce is pungent and overpowers the delicate tilapia. It would work better on a fish with more substance and flavor to it. Tilapia is best served by lightly dressing it with olive oil, real butter and lemon juice, lightly salted and broiled. We won't want this again.

text:
This recipe is great--I've already made it twice! I put each piece of fish in a foil packet (make sure you spray your foil first so the fish doesn't stick!) and then spread the topping on. Fold up the packet and grill for about 20 minutes...turns out perfectly and doesn't make the kitchen smell like fish!

country:

text:
What a quick and tasty recipe! Tried this tonight, and dealing with my 3 year old "trying to help" me in the kitchen took me longer than the actual prep and cook...I read a lot of the reviews, and changed this about the recipe. Added 1/2 tsp of garlic powder, a 1/4 of paprika and 1/2 cup of panko crumbs. I didn't have non stick spray or olive oil, so I just spritzed the foil covered cookie sheet with some butter spray, and lightly seasoned the fillets with some old bay seasoning. I broiled vein side down for 4 minutes, topped with cheese/crumb mix, and broiled for another 3...came out great and the family inhaled it! 
Now warning, if you don't like parmesan cheese, then don't use this recipe, it's a predominant flavor..And tilapia is a mild, somewhat delicate fish, that benefited from the stronger taste of the topping. And although I did change the origianl recipe to suit my tastes, I still give it a deserved 5 stars, for without the basis of the original recipe, I wouldn't have anything to build off of...

This is a delicious tilapia recipe.  I seasoned the filets on both sides with garlic powder, onion powder, oregano, basil, and seasoned salt before putting the topping on them.  No need for all the mayo and butter--adjust however you want.  I also added some bread crumbs to get a crispier topping.

text:
I have similar version of this recipe that will knock your socks off!  You line the bottom of a baking dish with sliced tomatoes, sprinkle about 1/2 cup of chopped Kalamata olives, add some lemon zest and squeeze lemon juice over the top and add salt and pepper.  Then lay the tilapia pieces over the top and spread the mayo-parmesean mix over the fish and bake at 450 for 20 to 30 minutes or until golden brown.  It is AWESOME!

text:
This is a wonderful base recipe! As I am a cook who does not always use exact measurements I made the following adjustments: Banged up some garlic crotons, Parmesan/Romano shredded cheese blend, Tony Chachere's Seasoning, Old Bay, Miracle Whip, and a little extra butter than called for (made extra topping). Topped the fish with that magical combo (most important do not over broil) and it was delectable. In the words of the infamous Rachael Ray...YUM-O!!! Served with egg noodles tossed with the extra topping and steamed broccoli. People could not get enough of this; so now I make it all the time!

text:
After over a 100 sterling reviews of this tilapia my two cents doesn't seem necessary, but for the doubters I would have to agree this is pretty darn tasty.  So simple.  I followed the recipe exactly and didn't alter any of the ingredients.  I did add a pinch extra parmesan, but really, can you ever have too much parmesan?  The flavor was excellent, prep time a breeze and all diners at my house were pleased and cleaned their plates.  I will make this again and recommend others try it too!  Tilapia can taste so boring, but this recipe added the punch it needs without an overpowering flavor.  Yummy.

This is one of the best broiled fish dishes I have had.  Every Lenten Season I struggle with how to cook fish.  (We don't really eat it the rest of the year. I like fish, I just don't know what to do with it.)  This recipe is very fast and easy.  The only thing I think it needed extra was a little more salt.  The 1/8 tsp. celery salt wasn't enough for our tastes.  This recipe is definately a keeper not only for Lent, but for the rest of the year as well.  Thank you for submitting this recipe.

text:
Loved it!  I am doing Weight Watchers so I made the following modifications:  sprinkled garlic salt directly on the tilapia and gave it a squeeze of lemon before broiling.  Broiled 2 min per side, then added a lighter version of the topping:  sprayed each filet with with a few shots of "I Can't Believe it's not Butter" spray, dabbed each piece with a bit of MIracle Whip, tossed on a scant sprinkle of fresh parmesan, added a little fresh-ground pepper and another squeeze of lemon.  Broiled 2 more min for a delicious, quick, and very healthy dinner!

text:
Modified Review.  We loved this seasoning blend so much that I had to try frying the Tilapia.  In a large, deep, skillet over medium heat, melt the butter and mayonnaise. Beat together one egg plus one tablespoon of water and 1/8 tsp salt.  Dredge filets in egg wash, then bread/cheese mixture and place in skillet and fry, uncovered, for approximately 4 minutes per side (until fish flakes easily with fork).  Remove to paper towel lined plate for a moment before placing on a platter.  YUM!   Original Review: Add 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp paprika, 1/4 tsp crushed red pepper flakes, 1/8 tsp Old Bay Seasoning, and use celery seed instead of celery salt. If you want to prepare and refrigerate the seasoning/cheese/breading mixture ahead of time, it cuts your “Ready” time – start to finish – to 10 minutes!  Size of the filets will affect broil time; I used very small (2 ounce) tilapia filets, and found the perfect broil time was 6 minutes.

It is now in permanent rotation at our house!

city:

country:
None
text:
I have used this topping recipe on several different kinds of fish - it works well with tilapia because tilapia can overcook easily and this topping protects the fish as well as adding a moisturizing factor to it - so the fish will hold well. It is also very good on salmon as it helps balance the "fishy" taste - and adds a bit of brightness to the overall taste. I like to zest the lemon and sprinkle a bit of it over the topping when it comes out of the oven for presentation. I've used this in several restaurants and it's always been a house favorite.

text:
Phenomenal.  

I bought 10 pieces of Tilapia (which ended up being just over 1.5 lbs.).  After making a batch of the topping, I realized it wouldn't be enough, so I made another.  I then broiled the fish for 2:30 on each side on the second-to-highest oven rack position, added gracious amounts of the topping to each piece, then broiled for about another 2:30 (until the topping was a little browned).  

Easy and wonderful.

text:
I used flounder and it tasted great. Read reviews before I started and added 1/2 tsp. paprika, 1/4 tsp. garlic powder, and a small amount of crushed red pepper flakes. Sprinkled the flounder with Old Bay seasoning on both sides, omitting the celery salt because the Old Bay has it in it.. Also used Low Fat Mayo. Delicious!!

text:
This was excellent, not to mention easy!  I used Monkfish because it is what we had and is similar in 'meatiness' to tilapia, and it came out great.  I not a huge fish fan and we are trying to eat more fish, so this is a keeper.  I'm eager to try it on some other types of fish as well.

text:
I had to add an edit because my fish-averse hubby got up for seconds tonight with the exclamation: "I was wrong - I like tilapia!" Thanks again for this little gem!
This is easy, delicious, and quick - mix up the topping before you start the fish under the broiler or you'll end up overcooking it. This is a forgiving recipe - after making it a couple of times, I don't measure the ingredients any more, and I can substitute seasonings depending on what I have on hand or am in the mood for. Thanks for a great weeknight family pleaser!

text:
Delicious- we thought the fish was very moist and favorful this way. I  did add some old bays seasoning to  the cheese mixture and  It took longer to cook -maybe our fish was thicker? I will be making this again. I scaled the recipe to 2 servings.  I also added 1 T. of  breadcrumbs and a dash of red pepper. I make this almost every week now and I served it  with rice,a vegetable and salad --  its very easy to make. My husband really likes it.

text:
My boyfriend loved loved loved it!!!! I did make a few changes to suit his taste and some comments from some previous reviewers. I omitted the celery salt but added garlic powder in its place, about a 1/4 - 1/2 a tsp. I also added a palm full of toasted unseasoned breadcrumbs. Other reviewers said it helped hold the sauce together better and it seemed to do just that. This is going to be a staple of our weekly diet. There are other spices and herb combos that I can't wait to try. Thanks for the great recipe!!

text:
Super Fast! Super Easy!! Super Delicious!!!  After reading the reviews I cut the butter in half & added 1/4 cup of panko to the topping, I also used Old Bay on the fish as many suggested.  Will make again, as many said if you change up the seasonings you can give it a whole new taste.  I also think I might try using crumbled Ritz crackers in place of the panko.  Really good versatile base recipe that you can twist to meet your tastes.

I've made this recipe a couple of times. The first time, it was good but not great. This time, I seasoned the fish prior to cooking it. One complaint the first time I made it was the topping seemed to thin out too much when placed under the broiler. I followed another reviewers recommendation and added breadcrumbs to the mixture to thicken it up a little during cooking. It was great and my family loved it.

userID:
2918973
Display Name:
Keri

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I purchased a box of frozen Tilapia from Walmart and tried one the other night. It was very fishy and I didn't like it at all. There are tons of individually wrapped fillets in the box so I figured I didn't want them to go to waste and searched for some recipes. Based on the many many positive reviews I thought this would be the one to try since I didn't even need to get ingredients from the store. I am HOOKED! This has to be one of the best recipes I have tried. My mods: I added some freeze dried onions, a dash of cayenne pepper, took away the celery salt (didn't have any), reduced the butter to well under a teaspoon (added more light mayo to make up for it), to finish off, I added panko breadcrumbs to each side and didn't even flip the fish. I baked at 370. The panko breadcrumbs keep the fish crispy. Yummy and NO MORE fishy taste at all. A+++ on this recipe. Who would have thought mayo and fish would go together so well?

Delicious!! Very easy and quick.  The whole family loved it.  Followed recipe exactly except: 1)didn't have onion powder so I finely chopped/minced a little bit of onion, 2)didn't have reg.mayo so I used Miracle Whip Light-reduced the amount a little just to cut calories, 3)sprinkled both sides of fish with fish/chicken grill seasoning.  Great dish if you're having company over.

text:
This recipe was fantastic! All my family raved about it, including my brother who HATES anything seafood. (He even asked for another piece!)I was a little worried at first as it took a little longer that the specified time to cook the fish in the grill (i'm from Australia we don't call it a broiler), but in the end it turned out perfectly. I doubled the sauce and used the rest to serve over the vegies, and will probably do the same next time. A couple of things i changed: I have never heard of the fish used in the recipe(tilipa), - maybe we don't have it in Australia - so i just used a white fish from the supermarket. I did not add the lemon to the sauce but served the fish with a slice of lemon to squeeze over for each individual's taste. I also didn't add celery salt, but used garlic flakes and garlic salt, as my family love garlic. 
I will definitely use this recipe again... Thanks!

text:
this recipe has very nice flavor.  i think that its a little greasy and could maybe take less butter or mayo to cut down the oil.  i didnt have celery salt so i just used garlic salt and i put fresh ground pepper and salt on the fish before i placed in the broiler.  also i think maybe this recipe would work better on a more hearty fish.  i really love the flavor of the ingredients i just think that perhaps the fish is a little too delicate for all that cheese and oils.

text:
DELICIOUS!!  Didn't have onion powder, celery salt or basil, but used salt free all purpose seasoning instead.  Seasoned fish and topped with MOST IMPORTANT parmesan topping.  Served with lemon rice and sliced tomatoes.  For the lemon rice use 1 C jasmine rice, 1 1/3 C chicken broth, 2 T lemon juice, 1-2 t lemon rind, 2 sliced up scallions and 2 T butter.  Cover and bake in preheated 350 oven for 40-45 minute--FANTASTIC.

text:
I followed this recipe verbatim- I don't know if it's fair of me to rate this because I do not like fish, but I've been trying very hard to incorporate it into my diet.  That being said, the cheese mixture was very tasty, well-balanced, and had a nice tang that went very well with the tilapia.  I only had 3 bites, too weirded out at the thought of eating fish, but that's my issue, not the recipe's ;)  Everyone else (normal peoeple who can eat fish) enjoyed, and agreed that it deserved 4 out of 5 stars (my boyfriend prefers fried tilapia, my sister likes tilapia simple, with just lemon/butter, etc.) Thank you for providing me with this recipe to try!

text:
This may be a good dish for people who don't like fish. My ex-husband didn't like fish, and he really liked this dish because of the topping, which is very strong and savoury.  My kids, who like fish, love this dish. It's a fast, easy dinner. Note that if the fillets are significantly different in size (thickness), some may be fully cooked while others are still raw in the middle. Just keep an eye on them as they cook.

I've been making this recipe for about a year and can't believe I haven't reviewed it yet.  Anybody who knows me knows that I would rather gouge out my own eyeballs with a fish hook than actually eat a fish, but this recipe is incredible!  I love it!! text:
Original 5/3/2017 review: Made this for my husband and myself tonight.  Fish was moist and topping was good.  I would definitely add breadcrumbs on top next time to make it crunchy.  I omitted the lemon juice and basil.  Used garlic powder and seasoned salt instead of onion salt and celery seed.  Keep an eye on the fish as the topping turns brown very quickly once the butter melts.

Updated 7/10/17
Ten years later and I am still making this recipe. I now use garlic and onion powder and a little sprinkling of Old Bay.

text:
This turned out delicious!  1/2 the recipe and tweaked a little of the measurements.  You can cut down on the butter a lot.  I added chopped artichokes to the mixture then topped it off with panko breadcrumbs.  Tasted delicious!  Broiling really makes the panko extra crispy with each bite.  You can edit the recipe by using low fat mayo and cut down on the butter.  I was too lazy and just used garlic powder, salt and ground pepper to spice it up.  Turned out way too good.  Served it with lemon orzo and it was a hit with my hubby!  Will serve this again soon!

text:
I usually bomb big time with fish but i wanted to try one more time...it paid off with this wonderful recipe! I did one minor change, or rather addition which i would recommend...i added buttered italian bread crumbs after i broiled the topping for 2 minutes and then i broiled it again for another minute or so until the crumbs were brown. The lemon flavor comes out beautifully and the texture is fabulous! I cannot wait to try this again and serve it to guests to impress them! Great with wild rice and a salad!

None
country:
None
text:
You can’t go wrong with this dish!!!  I've made it several times but last night I tried it without carefully reading the directions.  I put on the topping BEFORE the 1st broil - Wrong. When I realized what I'd done, I scrapped it off.  Then after turning the fish the 1st time, I put on the topping again - wrong again. I let it cook for 2 minutes then turned it over quickly so the topping wouldn't burn.  All in all by the final broil I sprinkled it with Old Bay (as suggested by Sheila in Texas) AND sprinkled bread crumbs and parsley before the final broil (as suggested by pjoy222).  No one knew the difference.  It's always great!!!

country:
None
text:
It's only 5 stars if you modify it. I took the others' advice and added garlic powder and paprika; I lessened the lemon; and added panko crumbs. I doubled the mixture a tad bit because I wanted to add it to both sides of the fish instead of just one side. Instead of broiling the fish and then adding the mixture, I spread half the mixture on, baked it for about 10 mins, and then broiled it for 5 minutes. Then I flipped it around and spread some more and did the same. It's delicious! If you want a spicy kick, add some crush pepper too.

So ridiculously easy, and so ridiculously tasty!  My husband isn't big on fish (he likes red meat more), and anytime he does have fish, he swears he has to have it with tartar sauce. I cooked for 2 min on one side, 2 min on the other, and 2 min with the cheese mixture.

text:
A KEEPER for sure!! I made it healthy by substituting greek yogurt for the mayo, and cut down Parmesean cheese by 1/4 c. (only because I ran out) I added 1/2 c. Panko bread crumbs ( to keep the topping on top) 1/4 tsp garlic, 1/4 tsp paprika. My husband normally doesn't care for Tilapia, but loved this dish and all 3 children...11y, 4y, 2y, ate it with pleasure. I will be making this again and will keep basic recipe and tweak it a little every now and then to keep it interesting. delicious, fast, and very easy.

country:
None
text:
Loved this!  So easy and quick...here are my adjustments.  In a small skillet, I simmered chopped garlic and fresh chopped basil (instead of dried basil) in 1 tablespoon butter for about 5-6 minutes.  After letting it cool a little, I added this to the mayonnaise mixture.  Didn't feel like going to the store, so I omitted the celery salt, and didn't miss it.  I added a bit more Parmesan, but this is just a personal preference.  I think the original amounts were fine, though some will prefer more or less lemon.  I think the mayo mixture would even be great on a fish sandwich.   This will be my new "go-to" dish when I need something quick and impressive for company!

Display Name:
annie_zerd

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe really masks the flavor of the fish and does so poorly. I highly recommend many people ditch this recipe and instead season their tilapia with some old bay or lemon pepper, then dredge in flour, then place on foiled pan with tabs of butter on each fish fillet. Bake at 350 for 20 mins. Once done, remove fish to a plate, foil it, and pour the melted butter/fish sauce into a pan, add 1 T butter, 1 T flour, mix on medium heat, add in splash of white wine, juice of 1/2 a lemon, chopped fresh italian parsley and pour over fish. That will knock this recipe out of the water.....forever.

text:
Wow. I can't believe I'm writing this bad review after over 2900 reviewers gave this such a great review. I made two batches of this recipe yesterday. I was so worried that my non-fish eating husnband would like this so I made one batch yesterday for lunch using reviewer "Shannon's" recommendations. I was sorry to say this batch had a very dry consistency and was tough to apply to the fish. With the bread crumbs you had to somehow spoon it on and even then it wouldn't stick to the fish. And the taste was just "ok". So later that night I made another batch and didn't make any modifications to the original recipe. Made it exactly according to the recipe. And I ended up cooking the three filets I had almost tripple the time suggested. The mayo/butter/lemon was sooooo moist it never seemed to get a nice crispyness to it. And the flavor was very mayo-ish. I was sooo hoping for a flaky fish which I know Tilapia can be. I broil it all the time with just a tiny bit of lemon and butter and garlic salt. Or sometimes just with Old Bay Seasoning. I was just hoping to cover up the fish with something my non-fish eating husband would like. He forced it down (for my sake) but later said don't bother with this recipe again. sigh. Sorry but I have to agree with him.

text:
I've never been a fish person at all -- made this recipe for my husband's sake.  Was I ever pleasantly surprised -- it's absolutely delicious (and not "fishy" tasting at all)!  I followed the recipe exactly (except for using celery salt...didn't have any).  I used a jelly roll pan lined with foil (and sprayed with Pam) and started with the vein side up so that it would be right-side up after coating.  My husband was thrilled with this fish and said it was better than a similar tilapia recipe he'd recently had at a nice restaurant.  Served with cole slaw and bowtie pasta (over which we drizzled a little of the sauce from the pan...so yummy).  Thank you very much for this fabulous recipe -- it's going into regular rotation in our household! :-)

Shug1983

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was wonderful.  I sprinkled both sides of the fish with Old Bay prior to broiling.  I used Krafts Italian Blends for the cheese. Problems I ran into: My oven has low and high settings on the broiler. Wasn't sure which to use, I went with Low and it turned out to be the right choice. I broiled both sides for 3 minutes.  When I put the cheese on top, the fish was already fully cooked before the cheese had properly melted.  Next time I will decrease the cooking time to 2 minutes per side.  Also, I misread the recipe and use the whole mixture for 2 fillets instead of 4.  Since I served it with Butter & Herb rice, it was a little too buttery tasting after the fact. Next time I will half recipe.  I'm excited to try this again next week, with what I've learned I know it will be even more delicious!

text:
Excellent, quick and easy to make! Needs a kick so I added the following: Start with the dark vein side up, season with Old Bay on both sides. Add the following to the Parmesan mix - 1/2 tsp paprika, 1/4 tsp minced garlic, 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes, 1/2 cup bread crumbs.

userID:
702086
Display Name:
Hannah
isPro:
False

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the tilapia standard in my home.  After using the recipe as-is a few times I decided I didn't like the runniness of the parmesan mixture and took several other reviewers' suggestions and a few of my own:

1/8 t garlic salt instead of celery salt

1/4 t paprika

1/4 t crushed red pepper flakes (slightly under 1/4 due to my finicky family)

1/2 c Italian bread crumbs

Dash of Tabasco sauce

My aunt said it tasted cajun, I say it just tastes good.  If you have sensitive tongues I would reduce the red pepper flakes and omit the Tabasco.  I  am going to substitute the lemon juice with lime next time too and see how it turns out.

text:
This recipe is absolutely delicious and very flavorful! Even my 6 year old who's a picky eater loves it. I also tried this recipe using chicken and it's as equally great. Although I did modify it a little by seasoning the meat first with season all, garlic powder as well as the other seasonings used in the recipe. I also bake the meat vs broiling it. I took some of the other reviewers advice by adding bread crumbs and garlic powder to the cheese mixture, and when time to add it, I turned the oven on broil just to melt the mixture until it starts to turn bubbly golden brown. I love the flavor of the cheese mixture so much that I double up on it. This will be on the menu every week in my home.

text:
I have been wanting to try this recipe for some time now!  Hubby and I thought this was great for such a quick meal.  If your tilapia is defrosted this can be on your table in 15 minutes, for that and also being somewhat healthy, and tasty, this is a winner.  I halved the recipe since I only had 1 lb. of filets and it was just the two of us eating, but I think I could have kept the topping amount the same because it spread a little thin.  I did everything that reviewer Shannon;) said to do (she's the first one under most helpful reviews) except I did keep the lemon juice.  We are trying to rotate more fish into our diet to eat healthier, and served this with baked potatoes and steamed green beans, and we felt healthier already! ;)
With 1500+ reviews, you really should try this dish, even if you hate it, its not an expensive or hard dish to prepare.

Display Name:
SOCAL REINER

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Never saw tilapia in the market before today. It looked like beautiful little thin white filets. The butcher said that it was very mild and not fishy. Remembered seeing this recipe so I bought a little piece and tested it on myself for lunch. This was very good and similar to something you'd get in a fancy restaurant. Scaled down the topping and cooked 3 minutes on each side under the broiler and 3 minutes to brown the topping.  This fish really doesn't have much flavor on its own but takes on what is in the topping.  Don't skimp on the topping. If you like garlic (we don't) I can see where so many reviewers added some. I might try a splash of Tabasco next time. If you're not wild about fish but think you should be eating some... I'd recommend this recipe... so easy  and ready in 10 minutes. Thank you Phoebe.

text:
What an awesome culinary delight!  My family loves this dish, especially when we remember to DOUBLE the topping recipe and separate out half of it to use as dipping sauce later.  To cut some of the fat (important when we're using more of the topping!), I use only about half the butter, substitute Miracle Whip Light for the mayo, and add more lemon juice for extra punch!  Only slightly less sumptuous, but still a rich and wonderful combination of flavors.  We've used the same method with other kinds of fish, too, and it always comes out great.  Thanks for sharing this recipe - it's a winner!

text:
DELICIOUS! I used "Just 2 Good" mayo, light margarine, and fresh Parmesan (grated it on a box grater, then chopped it fine in my food processor); cut the recipe in half for 4 fillets...my husband had 2, I shared 1 with my 23-month-old (who wasn't feeling well, but had no trouble eating lots!), and I now have some for my lunch tomorrow! Served it with rice pilaf and a tossed salad. Seasonings were nice & light, didn't overpower the delicate flavor of the fish. A new staple in the ol' recipe box...thanks!

region:

country:
None
text:
I applied the batter to both sides BEFORE it went into the oven. I didn't feel like taking the fish out three times in 10 mins since I was cooking quite a few other things and I was broiling on a grate. I only flipped the fish once and put a bit more batter onto the new side. I was very happy with the results. I was worried when I smelled the batter that the lemon was going to be too strong; I'm not a huge fan of lemon. However, to my surprise, it was delicious and the lemon flavor was not necessarily subtle but very smooth and the rich creamy texture was amazing.

!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing recipe. Pretty easy and fast. Additional tips: (1) Have fun mashing the mixture with your hands, which will warm it up and make it easier to spread on the fish. (2) Watch the fish under the broiler because it's easy to overcook it. If the fish is very close to the element, two minutes tops each side before adding the topping. (3) Not too much mayonnaise or it will come out too sour. (4) Don't take it out of the broiler until the topping has a nice golden color with some brown spots.

text:
I don't mind when people give reviews of a recipe they made changes to as long as they are fair about it. "I boiled my grilled cheese sandwich instead of grilling it and it was terrible, so I gave this recipe 1 star". Ok, not cool. But advice from people who have tried the recipe many times and added to it is great. I have come to my best ideas based on not just the recipes, but the thoughts and ideas of reviewers on this site. I made the topping for this recipe exactly as specified and tasted it before putting it on my tilapia. It was really good! Then I took some of Shannon's suggestions and made it even better. Kept everything like the recipe, but added 1/4 teaspoon each of garlic powder and paprika. This took the recipe from over 4 stars to a 5. Ether way it was delicious, but to be fair I am giving the original recipe a 4.75. Would definitely make it that way again but love it even more with the slight changes. Thanks to both Phoebe and Shannon for making me a movie star tonight. This is my absolute favorite fish dish ever. Everyone loved it!

text:
Delicious!  We love fish, but tilapia has usually left me cold - it's a little too mild-flavored.  This topping adds a lot of flavor.  I took the suggestions of adding onion and garlic powder, also panko (less than 1/2 cup), and sprinkled on a little bit of Old Bay while broiling the fish before putting on the topping.  We'll be having this again!

text:
4.5 stars; I did not use celery salt or lemon juice.  I added 1/4 bread crumbs, 1/4 tsp paprika, and 1/4 garlic powder.  Sauce was very strong.  Next time I wouldn't use as many bread crumbs, would not add the paprika, and would add lemon juice.  VERY EASY TO MAKE.  I did not flip the fish.  I broiled (hi) about 4 mintues without sauce and 1 minute with the sauce.  TRIED IT A SECOND TIME: 5 STARS now- I added 1/8 cup of bread crumbs and 1/4 tsp garlic powder.  Added the lemon juice and didn't use the paprika.  Will make this frequently!

text:
I just made this last night, and loved it! I followed the recipe exactly, making 4 servings. I did think it was just a touch salty, so if you want to reduce that you could probably try celery seed instead of the salt, like other reviewers have mentioned. Oh, and I used the dry grated parmesan from a can, even though I wasn't sure if that was correct. It does cover up the flavor of the fish, so if you like the taste of fish it may not be for you. Luckily, I like the texture of fish a lot more than the taste, so this was wonderful.

text:
This was excellent, I did make some changes due to the fact that we watch our fat and calorie intake. I seasoned the fish with a small amount of Sazon on both sides and broiled for 3 minutes. I then flipped the filets and topped with a small amount of chipotle mayo (fat free mayo mixed with chipotle and adobo) some garlic and onion powders and then just sprinkled some parm on top and returned to the broiler. I used very little mayo and skipped the butter all together, it was very good.

text:
I made the original recipe and it was a bit too acidic for my husband and son. I didn't care for the celery seed seasoning. So the next time I only used 1 1/2 tsp lemon juice and substituted garlic powder for the celery seasoning and it was a consensus- delicious. Also, my broiler has two settings; I did mine on high for about 3 mins, flipped, ~3 mins, put parmesan sauce on, in for about 2 mins and it was perfect. My filets were about 1" thick. Will definitely make again with the few alterations. Thank you for a great recipe.

text:
I've made this recipe a dozen times before attempting to write a review.  In a word - awesome!!    Ingredients are readily available in your kitchen.  Dish preparation time is minimal and the taste, oh the taste, phenomenal.  I've deviated from the recipe by adding 1/4 teaspoon of Sneaky Pete hot sauce to the Parmesan cheese toping.    Tilapia prepared this way is much tastier than breading & frying.  Better for you too I suspect.

text:
Wonderful!  My mother (who hates seafood) marked this dinner as one for the records, as it was her FIRST time ever voluntarily going back for a second helping of fish!  I made some minor changes based on what was in the cubbard and previous reviews.  Because of what I had on hand, I omited the celery salt and halved the lemon juice.  I added a few tablespoons of bread crumbs (1/4 of a piece of dried bread - crushed), because of previous reviews.  It was a wonderful addition to the texture.  I only had 1.5 lbs. fish, so the extra sauce I poured around the fish (on the aluminum foil) and it browned beautifully.   I used margerine instead of butter and light mayo made with olive oil, as it was what I had.  Results still excellent.  This was my first time making fish, and it was a hit!  Thank you so much.

WOW! This is an excellent recipe! Just a few minor change-ups. text:
I absolutly love this recipe!  Since I've discovered I've made it at least once a week because it is so quick easy and delicious.  I took other reviewers advice and dust both sides of the tilapia with Old Bay seasoning and always use the butter / mayo combo and use whatever spices I'm feeling that night, garlic, onion, celery salt, basil, parsley - really whatever I grab first.  I've also found that adding just a a teaspoon or so of breadcrubs helps the sauce stay on the fish better.  Thanks for such a great and versatle recipe.

text:
Updated Rating April 12th, 2009  I made this about 10 times since my first rating.  I have to change my rating to 5 stars!! the first time was my first time making fish and I didn't do a good job.  When I made this I put the topping on the raw fish and popped it in the oven.  I didn't broil it or nothing.  It came out just "ok" but the second time I made it I read the recipe more throughly.       Okay, so I made this tonight and I made a mistake- I used miracle whip this time thinking I could change it up a bit.  NO! don't use miracle whip! It completely takes away from the taste of the fish and parmesan cheese.  You already add in lemon juice for "tang" so the miracle whip doubles the "tang" way to much.  It was hard to enjoy this fish tonight.  Just thought i'd give all you cookers out there a heads up...:)

text:
Absolutely delicious are the only two words I can think to discribe this dish.  We're not a "fish eating" family, so to find a recipe that everyone liked was a miracle.  My mother-in-law who lives with us is recovering from open heart surgery and fish is recommended for her to eat weekly.  I modified this recipe to make it more "heart friendly" by using low fat mayonnaise and Promise spread instead of the butter.  It was received so well at our dinner table last evening that I sent a copy of the recipe with her to her cardiac rehab classes to share with the dietitian, nurses, and other patients in her class.

text:
I absolutely love this recipe. I did alter it based on some of the other reviewers comments per below:

Use celery seed rather than celery salt. Add 1/2 tsp. paprika, 1/4 tsp. garlic powder and 1/4 tsp. crushed red pepper flakes. I use the Olive Oil Mayo that's better for you. Add some panko bread crumbs to the cheese mixture. 

And I double the entire sauce mixture just because I like more toppings. This is restaurant quality fish!

Fantastic for my husband, who eats fish because he should, not because he actually likes it. city:

None
country:
None
text:
I did not intentionally set out to spruce up this recipe. I thought I had all of the ingredients that the recipe called for, but I barely had any of them!!! So I kept improvising...I did not have tilapia, I had whiting. I did not have lemon juice, I used apple cider vinegar. No Basil, I used dried parsley. No celery salt, I used a dash of celery seed. The only ingredients that matched the recipe were Mayo, butter(unsalted), and parmesan cheese. I followed the broiling instructions and placed the "paste" on the fish...I decided to sprinkle a scant coating of Italian bread crumbs and sesame seeds on top. The fish tased great! The bread crumbs made a light crunchy crust. Every bite I ate , I was pleasantly surprised. It seems to me, that the basic broiling instructions paired with your own paste concoction, can make a really nice fish dinner.

text:
This is an awsome recipe. The best fish i've ever made. But beware! If the filets are thin, skip the second step. after cooking the fish for 3 minuts, flip them and dont cook them for "another few minuts" flip them and immediatly put the seasoning on. Cook the for 3 more minuts and serve. They will be juicy and PERRRRFECT!

text:
This is a delicious fish recipe! You can really make it with any kind of white flaky fish there is. If you want to make the topping a little more fancy, mix in fresh crab meat it will taste like a million bucks. Also if you have a hard time getting fresh fish, soak your fish fillets in milk for a couple of hours in the refrigerator, this helps reduce the fishy taste/smell.

Pretty Good! as a rule, I can't stand the flavor of cooked mayo on fish. So to get around this, I subsituted. Instead of 3 tablespoons of mayo, I used 1 tablespoon of mayo and two tablespoons of sourcream. Excellent! I also sprinkled some paparika on the fish before the final broiling for added color and apeal. Next time I do this recipe I will add some garlic powder to the party and after broiling, I will toss some chives or green onions on top for a perfect garnish.

Finally got around to trying this tonight (had to see what all the fuss was about!), and it was really incredible! I'm not a big fish fan (I'll eat it for the health value, but don't love it), but the topping made this a new family favorite...even my 3 yr. old ate it up! text:
I followed Shannon's suggestion and added bread crumbs (I used roasted garlic, all I had on hand), paprika, garlic powder and red pepper flakes.  I also sprinkled the filets with Old Bay on each side as suggested.  This was one of the best fish dishes I have ever had, let alone prepared myself.  I don't have very many fish dishes in my repertoire that I feel comfortable with, but this was so easy and as long as you watch your times for the broiler, a no-fail dish.  This will definitely be added to our regular rotation.  I can't wait to make it again!

text:
I thought the recipe was fantastic. My fiance doesn't care much for fish and he finished this. I did make a couple changes which didn't add any time, but I am sure added in flavor. I put slightly soften butter in the mini-chopper with 1/4 c white onion, 1 stalk of celery and a tbsp of minced garlic. I ommited the celery and oinion powders. Otherwise the recipe was the same and was terrific. I did not find it runny- however I cooked the fish on a lower rack and then popped in in the top rack after adding the topping which may have helped keep it together.

text:
This recipe was AWESOME!!!  I absolutely love to eat seafood, but am terrified to cook it.  Well not any more!  This fish was so easy to make, and my husband really liked it.  I took another readers advice and added a little bread crumbs to hold the cheese sauce on the fish.  I also added a little garlic and instead of using onion powder I used onion flakes.  (that's all I had) Oh and I used the fresh shredded parmesan.  Bake until the cheese is golden brown.  
The BEST!!!  Thank you for this recipe!!

text:
We love this recipe - so fast and easy.  Goes well with Parmesan Couscous (which also cooks fast) and a salad.  

Two tips from my experience: (1) make sure the butter is softened but not melted to help keep it on top of the fish, and (2) turn on your kitchen fan because the butter that melts down off the fish tends to burn
Review:

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Didn't have tilapia on hand, so I used mahi-mahi filets I got from Costco the other day.  

I, like many of the others, tweaked a bit.
I didn't want the sauce to slide off as many had complained about, so I added about 1/3 cup of breadcrumbs to the Parm/butter mix.  I also added about a clove of minced garlic, a dash of crushed red pepper, and some dried basil/oregano.  
I also VERY lightly sprinkled the fish with Blackening seasoning on each side, prior to broiling the fish.

My husband has begged me to make this often, and he hates fish. So you know it had to be good!

text:
This was a really, really good tilapia recipe! I omited the celery salt (didn't have any), but noticed no differenece. One thing I have noticed about tilapia - it tastes much better fresh. Don't buy it frozen (too chewy). The parmesan cheese was a great compliment to the lemon juice (which was not strong at all). Don't forget to keep your oven door cracked a bit while broiling, or you'll burn your fish!

Moist, flavorful, easy, and perfect...the best compliments I can give! This is definitely moving up into regular rotation, as it was the quickest meal I've made in a long time. I could have made it even quicker, but I can't bring myself to use the parmesan in the can. Even with grating my own parm, it was a 15 minute dinner. I served this with "Real Poutine" from this site for a fun (artery-clogging!) take on fish and chips. Excellent meal! I'll be trying this again with other fish...I bet the topping would be killer on salmon!

text:
My family really loved this recipe. The sauce was awesome. I made it exactly as the recipe stated and it turned out perfectly! Definitely restaurant quality. Thanks for sharing!

Update: I've made this recipe many times and have a couple of modifications that we really like. I add 1/2 cup Panko breadcrumbs to the topping mixture. I also saute the fish in a with a little oil and butter on the stove, instead of putting it under the broiler. It gives it a bit of a crunchier taste. I then add the topping and broil it for 2 minutes. Yummy!

country:
None
text:
Great fish recipe! I substituted romano for the parmesan and it was delicious.

TIP: I found that I hadn't broiled it long enough at the beginning and ended up with my cheese topping nice and brown but the thickest part of the fish was undercooked.  So I turned off the broiler element, moved the fish to the lowest rack and let it bake at 350 degrees for another 4-5 minutes.  The middle cooked through without further browning the top.

text:
This is a great recipe. You can change it just a little bit here and there to suit whatever you're making. For the Tilapia, we used grated cheese, added a little extra pepper, and some garlic. I also sprinkled a little cajun on the filets before putting them in the oven. Folks need to make sure the fish is close enough to the broiler if they're having a problem with the texture. It's only 2-3 inches away.

text:
This has to be one of my favorite recipes out there.  5 stars for Non-fish lovers too.  Kids like it and it's simple/ easy to make.   Just remember as with any recipe- use FRESH ingrediants.  Get the fish fresh if you can- stay away from Frozen. Use fresh Parmesan cheese and you will notice the difference.   Buy it freshly grated at your local grocer's cheese section.    I've also used this topping on other fish and chicken-  it's mouth watering!

text:
Wow!  This was absolutely delicious!  I messed up and used 1/3 cup mayo instead of 3 tbs...BUT, it was just more similar to baked cod, and the sauce came out yummy and creamy.  I did not use onion powder, and doubled the fresh squeezed lemon juice (love lemon with fish).  I also lighly buttered, salted and peppered during the initial broiling.  I cooked it 2 1/2 minutes on each side, and 4 minutes in the end.  The fish was mouth-watering moist and the parmesian sauce was a beautiful light-golden bubbly brown.  I would recommend the 1/3 mayo as I used, to create a creamy cheesy sauce (if you don't mind the calories)!  Thanks for the recipe - everyone raved!

None
country:
None
text:
Since I discovered this delicate,mild tasting inexpensive fish 6 months ago, I buy it almost weekly. There is not a lot of recipes out there for this kind of fish. This was good but none of us thought it to be outstanding. I used 1.47 pounds of fish,not 2 and didn't have any extra sauce for serving on top of rice. I would double the sauce next time. I didn't have celery salt, so I used a pinch of celery seed and 1/8 tsp. salt. I think next time I will add some garlic powder, and try using dill weed in place of basil. I will definately experiment with this. Maybe I was expecting more from all the great reviews but it was a nice way to prepare this and fast and easy. I would try this sauce on tomato slices(broiled) and even chicken. Thanks Phoebe!

text:
I have made this three times and have enjoyed it every time.  It is very simple.  I substituted Miracle Whip for Mayo once and it wasn't as good. Stick to the mayo. I have made it with more cheese sauce and with less sauce.  It just depended on what I felt like eating.  We love fish so less sauce is better for us because we want more of a fishy taste.  When we had company over we would use more of the cheese sauce.  Excellent either way.

text:
This is a tasty and quick way to prepare fish. Catfish could be used in place of tilapia as the flavor and texture are similar. Would be a good dish for the first time fish cook to make since it's hard to mess up. Also, this recipe pleases the palates of people who don't normally like fish. Tilapia should have a light, fresh taste, not fishy and strong. Most of the time when fish is fishy tasting it's from overcooking it.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-06-18T09:17:48.853
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
4447003
Display Name:
BrittSJ
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
52
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone who ate it fell in love! I made a few changes. First, when making the mix, I eliminated the mayo. I've been running and I don't need that in my diet plus my boyfriend hates mayo. Instead of lemon juice I used lime juice and i eliminated the basil and replaced it with dried parsley and used regular salt instead of celery salt because I didn't have any. I added garlic powder, cayenne pepper, and paprika to the mix. I added just a little water to not make it so thick but just a little. I also had some rolls on hand so i broke it up into crumbs and added it to the mix. Seasoning the tilapia is key. I used old bay from a suggestion from another user and seasoned both sides but not heavy. Make sure you watch the fish so to not overcook it. I broiled 2 1/2 minutes on one side and 2 minutes on the other. Then I added the mix which was like a paste and put it back in for 2 1/2 minutes until it browned a little and got crispy. The butter melted on the fish a little which made it tasty. I served it with lightly seasoned white rice and bell peppers that I sauteed and added in when i broiled the fish. Everyone gobbled it down!

text:
My husband buys tilapia, and now that he is deployed, I'm stuck with it in the freezer. I didn't know what to make with it, as I can't seem to find a recipe that makes this fish tasty or filling. I found this recipe and decided to try it since I had fresh Parmesan cheese and all the other ingredients on hand. I loved that it was quick, easy and delicious and can be served on top of rice. This is definitely a keeper and I will continue to grate fresh Parmesan into the mix, as it really packs flavor into this dish. Thank you for this recipe. I finally have a quick go-to for tilapia. :)

text:
Better than I could have thought. My 6 year old who never touched fish before in his life ate two whole fillets! I sprinkled a bit of old bay on before initial broiling. The timing on the recipe was absolutely perfect. As suggested by another reviewer I did add a small amount of parm break crumbs to the mixture so it would all brown nicely. If you do this, make double the topping mixture. Other than that small add on, I wouldn't change a thing. This will become a regular on the meal rotation! Awesome flavor, not too overwhelming. Great texture (esp w the added splash of bread crumbs) and for once, perfect cooking times on the original recipe. Give it a whirl!!!!

text:
I'll be honest, I loved the way this recipe sounded so I wanted and did try it.  I am trying to cook more healthy so I made my own changes just for my benefit.  I omitted the butter and mayo and used non fat Greek yogurt for the topping. I kept the herb mixture the same.  I added an 1/8 cup of bread crumbs to hold it together and it worked very well. The flavor of the fish was there and the topping was a nice compliment to it.  I will make this again for sure.

text:
Like all other reviewers, I LOVED this! I am a terrible cook and can mess up the easiest of recipes. I thought for sure I'd either burn the fish or mess up the cheese topping. It came out GREAT! I followed the recipe exactly, save for the celery salt I left out and the addition of some paprika, garlic powder and some bread crumbs on top for the last two minutes of broiling. It was delicious! My boyfriend who typically doesn't trust my cooking looked it over with a suspicious eye but ate every morsel. Highly recommend for even the worst of cooks! The only change I would make is I loved the cheese sauce so much I'll double it next time.

text:
Very good.  Can vary the spices to suit your tastes.  Definitely needs more salt (& I rarely salt things -- but fish, in general, needs a good bit of salt to give it flavor) -- I used 1/2 t. garlic salt.  Also, I bake at 375 for 15-18 minutes, rather than broil (as I don't like the spattering, sizzling in my oven!)

This is fantastic!  After reading a lot of the reviews I made the following changes:

1.  Instead of celery salt, I used celery seed and than added a little additional salt.
2.  I added the same amount of panko crumbs as I did Parmesan cheese.  (1/2 cup parmesan cheese, 1/2 cup panko crumbs)
3.  I added 1/2 tsp paprika

This is DELICIOUS!!!

text:
My family loved this recipe.  It was easy and flavorful.  Followed the many recommendations: adding 1/2 tsp paprika, 1/4 tsp garlic powder and 1/2 cup bread crumbs.  And,  sprinkling fish with Old Bay Seasoning.
Would eliminate lemon juice next time--too tangy.  Would add 2 T of white wine maybe.  Found it hard to spread evenly on fish.  Will try warming mixture in microwave to soften it more.

Display Name:
Tracy Petit Berns

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/59051.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really great. I was surprised that parmesan would taste so good on fish (and so was my boyfriend)! I did add a little bit of bread crumbs to the cheese mixture, to help out the texture, but in the end, it didn't really matter because the topping doesn't stay under the broiler long enough to really crisp up anyway. So, although a bit on the mushy side, the result was a delicious creamy topping. I recommend broiling on LOW, as when I turned up to high for this last step, the topping quickly started to blacken, but did not get crispy. Delicious!
Review:
Rating:

userID:
8875803
Display Name:
Suzi Qz
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
5
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1789585.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious, I am not exaggerating. I made a few adjustments based on other reviewers suggestions, and a few of my own tweaks. I added garlic power, instead of onion powder. I skipped the basil and added fresh thyme, and baby dill to the mayonnaise mixture, this gave it a very fresh taste, that cut back slightly on the richness of the mayonnaise and butter. I also added paprika, and red [pepper flakes, and I sprinkled the fillets with old bay before broiling, as suggested by reviewer. The best addition was that of bread crumbs suggested by another person. I used panko breadcrumbs in with the mixture, and it gave it wonderful crispy crunch. I am definitely going to make this again. The fish was a perfect translucent color, and flaked beautifully. I recommend this recipe to anyone looking for something quick, easy, and tasty. If you want a truly superb meal, however, follow the suggestions of other reviewers.

This was so easy and delicious. I broiled on high and added the old bay seasoning and paprika along with garlic salt because I didn't have celery salt and it was so good.  My fish wasn't thawed yet so I put in plastic bag with water (they were individually wrapped) and they defrosted pretty quick. The whole family enjoyed them.  Thank you!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy, delicious recipe that has lends itself to a host of variation.  When I first went to make it, I realized I was out of Parmesan cheese, so I decided to go for more of an herb recipe.  I minced up some garlic and fresh thyme and mixed it in with the mayo, lemon, salt and pepper.  Once I laid the fish out on the broiler pan, I sprinkled them with Italian breadcrumbs.  I like the Parmesan as well when I have it, but won't fret.  Next time I will try it fresh basil and oregano, and definitely the garlic.  Awesome recipe!

I must start off by saying I was apprehensive about tilapia to begin with. So last night I was running behind and I needed something quick and easy for a last minute dinner!  I didn't have high hopes.  Found this recipe and I'm SO glad I did.  I didn't change anything except replacing the Parmesan with Dubliner cheese. It was a HUGE hit with my entire family!  The flavor was incredible!  My kids (2&4) gobbled it up and my husband raved about it!  Served it with some brown rice and tangy coleslaw.  Thanks for a great & (easy) recipe. Can't wait to make it again!

text:
I LOVED this with my changes.  As is, I would give 3.5 stars.  I soaked fillets in milk, seasoned, and prebaked 3 minutes pulling out and flipping over.  I combined mixture, sans lemon juice and basil, added cayenne, parsley and panko crumbs and coated the top portion of filets only.  Baked at 400 for another 5 minutes and let filets sit for 1-2 minutes.  Served over rice and with a green bean and tomato medley sprinkled with parmesan cheese.  The fish was so JUICY AND TENDER and the panko added a nice crunch!

Display Name:
RachelPerp

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe several times, each time a little bit differently depending on what ingredients I have on hand - it's very versatile and ALWAYS FAST AND DELICIOUS. 

Reducing the mayo and/or butter doesn't sacrifice any flavor and can even help brown the topping since you get a less runny mixture and proportionately more cheese. Also, I often exchange the celery salt/onion powder for garlic salt. Yum =)

Tilapia is cheap, almost always sustainably farmed, and very healthy! If possible try to buy tilapia from your local farmers' market - the more local (and thereby the fresher) the fish, the less "fishy" the taste. Tilapia is a quite mild white fish which is the main reason that people who normally don't like fish or seafood often like it; however, it can get unpleasantly fishy if you don't freeze or cook it within a couple days. 

Bon Apetit!

Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
5145491
Display Name:
CurlyCaramelCutie
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:
410
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4914086.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this while on vacation for my extended family.  They LOVED it and they are NOT fish eaters!  We were at a time share so we didn't have all of the ingredients.  We used low fat mayo but real  butter, salt substitute, black pepper, Old Bay, & lime instead of lemon juice.  No basil or celery salt, we didn't even have onion left by the time I made it!  They still loved it!  I mixed fresh bread crumbs, because that's what we had, with the topping ingredients and the topping still turned out great!  I suggest bread crumbs every time, they hold a bit of the cheese flavor in!  We had an electric oven so I cooked the fish without the topping further away from the heat, then after adding the topping, cooked it close to the heat.  Texture was perfect, still juicy but firm and perfectly done!  I have gas at home so I'll have to see how it'll work at home but all in all, great recipe!!!  You can modify it to suit your tastes like all recipes so give it a shot!

text:
This is a very tasty, very easy preparation for tilapia!  I took other reviewers' advice and sprinkled the fillets with Old Bay before broiling (Tony Chachere's would be good too) and I added a few Tbs. of panko to the butter mixture, which gave the topping a really nice texture once it was broiled.  Subbed garlic powder for onion since that's what I had on hand.  Delicious, fast, and my kids loved it!

text:
This was probably the best fish I have ever had!  I really only made a few changes.  1) I hate mayo so I substituted sour cream 2) Used celery seed instead of salt 3) Added 1/8 tsp. garlic powder 4) I lined a baking sheet with foil and sprayed the foil with nonstick spray 5) Broiled with the rack as close to the broiler as I could for 5 minutes.  I did not turn the fish over 6) Put the mixture on the fish and broiled two more minutes

country:

text:
Best tilapia I have made and my 8-year-old son said "This is so good!  The best fish I've ever had."   I didn't even have lemon juice and I don't like celery salt but this was still delicious.  When adding cheese mixture I sprinkled panko crumbs over the top and this is really the key.  It made the fish light and crispy instead of soggy which can sometimes happen with a butter/mayo mixture.  I would not make recipe without the panko because it's that good!  You could make this lower calorie by omitting the mayo which I will try next time-I don't think I will notice the difference.  I actually felt bad that my husband was working because we didn't leave him any leftovers. :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-03-02T14:04:58.757
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
6661472
Display Name:
kittcourt
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
15
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ADD FRESH BASIL AND TOMATO: This was one of the best white fish recipies I've ever had.  I just added my own twist by laying fresh basil leaves and tomato slices on top.  It was delicious! I sprinkled Old Bay on the fish like others suggested, and I didn't add dried basil to the sauce.  I cooked as suggested, but once the sauce on the fish stated to brown (about 1 minute) I took it out and laid fresh basil leaves on top (about 3-4 leaves per filet, just to cover a good portion of the surface area with a single layer).  Then I dabbed a tiny bit of sauce on each leaf to act as a glue and laid a round thin tomato slice over that (one tomatoe slice per basil leaf).  I sprinkled a little salt and a pinch of sugar on the tomato to caramelize in the broiler and put the fish back in for another minute.  The fresh basil added so much more flavor than dried basil and the soft tomato and fresh herb cut the super cheesy richness.  It was a perfect compliment to the sauce and also looked beautiful.  My boyfriend loved this dish.  It's like a tilapia bruschetta!

text:
This was good, don't get me wrong.  But as an avid fish cooker, I just didn't find it as insanely amazing as most people rated it.  It was a bit messy, as well.  I ended up adding garlic and old bay, and squeezing extra lemon on this when done, because it just needed a bit more kick.  When it comes down to it, nothing can beat simply marinating fish in some lemon and olive oil with a ton of fresh garlic and a bit of salt and pepper for an hour or so, then sauteeing it on a hot stove for a few minutes (painless, fast, and less clean up).  I like to try new things, nonetheless.  Thanks, it was enjoyable.

text:
In the summertime, we like to BBQ salmon, but other than that, I really don't know how to cook fish!  So, in trying to incorporate fish into our diets for good health, I decided to buy Tilapia.  I had no idea how to prepare it, so I looked for the easiest and best-reviewed recipe I could find.  And here it was!  This Broiled Tilapia Permesan was absolutely DEE-LISH!!  I sprinkled a little bit of garlic pepper on the fish before cooking, and it was heavenly.  In the creamy topping, I used low-fat sour cream in place of the mayo, and about half the Parmesan cheese.  Excellent Tilapia, and it couldn't have been easier to prepare!  Served it with fresh-steamed broccoli and whole wheat cous-cous.  This one's a keeper!! :)

text:
I'm very impressed.  My wife is allergic to most fish, so I don't get it often.  I made a few adjustments, some out of necessity.  I followed other reviews and added old bay directly on the fish, and garlic in the sauce.  I also used dried lemon peel in lieu of the juice, and subbed celery seed for celery salt.  When it came time to get the parm, I realized I had none.  So I finely shredded some whole milk mozzarella, and it worked out just fine.  I will try this again with the mozz, parm, romano and possibly a little asiago.  Thanks!

None
text:
This is the BEST fish recipe I have ever tried.  It is so quick, easy, and absolutely delicious!  I do not agree at all with one reviewer who said this sauce is too pungent for a mild fish like tilapia.  I think this sauce complements tilapia wonderfully.  Everyone in my home loved it, and that's saying a lot, since my youngest son is such a picky eater.  

I only made a couple slight changes (only because I was using what I had on hand).  I didn't have onion powder, so I used garlic powder.  Also, I didn't have FRESH parmesan cheese, so I combined grated parmesan cheese from a plastic canister I had and fresh mozzarella.  Other than that, I followed directions.

This recipe definitely makes you want to add more fish to your diet.  Thanks for sharing!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was studying for finals and needed a quick and easy recipe for Talapia and luckily I found this recipe. I didn't have all the ingredients so I had to improvise. I pulled out my food processor and I dumped in the parmesan cheese, frozen margarine and mayo. Whiz it up to break down the margarine and then I added salt, pepper, onion powder, old bay seasoning, celery seed, paprika, and dried parsley. It was really thick so I included some half-n-half and water. I folded some shredded cheese into the mix. I put the Talapia in a glass baking dish and dumped the mix on top then wrapped it in foil. OMG it was amazing and it’s fantastic with brown rice!!! Thanks for posting this recipe.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe for over a year now, and it is by far my favorite tilapia recipe.  I sometimes add more parmesan.  Sometimes I also double the parmesan sauce.  When I do this, I have to take the fish out after broiling it with the sauce, transfer to another dish and broil it until it's as brown as I like it.  If I don't transfer the fish when I double the sauce, it ends to kind of mushy and never sets up.  This is no fault of the recipe or the author of the recipe; it's just because sometimes I like extra sauce on top and need to adjust for that.

text:
this recipe is so "off the hook" no pun intended :O)... anyhow, I have used it on several different types of white fish.  I also like to sprinkle the fish with Old Bay and about 1/2 a cup of bread crumbs before doing anything, then I also add paprika, garlic poweder and a smidge of crushed red pepper to the mayo mixture, as for the cheese, I use whatever I have on hand.  I have used cheddar, mozzarella, mexican mix cheese and italian mix cheese.  I like the cheddar the best but that is just me.  This recipe my children request and they hate white fish, now when I say white fish for dinner they say "is the mayo one" if I say yes, they stay home for dinner and nobody mysteriously comes down with an ill tummy before dinner ;O)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first time I ever made tilapia and only the second time I had ever eaten it!  After having tilapia in a seafood dish while on vacation, I thought I'd try to make it when I got home.  After looking for a recipe, this one was intriguing and I was really glad I tried it.  I made several modifications only because I was trying to make it lower in WW points!  :)   I mixed together (approximate amounts) 2T. reduced fat mayo, 2T. romano cheese, 2T. butter, 1/2 tsp. garlic powder, and black pepper.  I also seasoned both sides of the filet with Old Bay, broiled for 3 minutes on the dark vein side, flipped and spread on the mix and broiled for an additional 4 minutes and it was done!  Super easy, super fast, and OH SO TASTY!

This is the best fish recipe.  I took the advice of past reviews and added 1/8 teaspoon cayenne pepper, 1/2 cup of Panko bread crumbs, and 1/8 teaspoon of garlic powder. Some omit the lemon juice in the recipe but I kept it and like the flavor it adds.  Also, I dusted the fish with Old Bay prior to broiling.    My kids loved it and my husband said in any restaurant one would pay $28 for such a dish!

It was a total hit!!! I love seafood but never really learned any recipies as my mother HATES it!! I always had to go out to eat if I wanted any. But yea, ABSOLUTE HIT!! I reccomend this to someone who wants a super quick and easy meal that everyone will love. I did a few tweaks to it as well though: Instead of onion powder in the mix I put onion salt straight on the fillets (both sides) to broil before the mix was added. Also used celery seeds because I had no celery salt. I doubt that'll make a huge differance though. Added garlic!!! Other than that, I have to say, this recipie made me feel like a 5 star chef and everyone loved it. Served with a ceasar salad, raspberry italian dressing, garlic bread and blackberry merlot... Which I dont suggest lol Thanks Phoebe!!!

userID:
1561418
Display Name:
Whydidntithinkofthat
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7194948.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just LOVE this recipe and have made it so many times for my husband who especially loves it and would eat it every night if I would make it that often! I've introduced it to my family (sister, mom, inlaws) and they have adored it as well. It's just the perfect combo of lemon and parmesan, a hint of basil etc. I must say though, that I do use less butter and am generous with the fresh lemon juice. It's such a versatile recipe. This is what I do: I line a baking sheet (cookie sheet) with foil and spray with Pam, then sprinkle salt and pepper over what I have just sprayed. Then I place the Tilapia down. I usually get 3 filets which equal 1 lb of fish. (I adjust the sauce ingredient amounts according to how much fish I have). I broil the fillets for about 4 min, then flip, and broil for 4 min more, then cover with the lemony cheese sauce and broil again for about 4 min. Granted, I don't like my fish undercooked, but don't like it overcooked either. I always have such great success with this recipe. This will be in my recipe box for years to come and will be most definitely passed on! It's fantastic!

text:
This was incredible!  I would suggest not varying the recipe too much.  I did, however, make it even easier by shaking Tones Salmon & Seafood seasoning on both sides before broiling.  That added lemon and dill, among other flavors to the fish.  Then I spread the butter/mayo/parmesan mixture on top and broiled a couple more minutes until brown and bubbly.  I served this with rice, steamed broccoli, and sliced tomatoes.  My husband said that this fish has replaced steak as his favorite meal...how about that?!

text:
I've been making this recipe (as written) for a while and my family loves it. Tonight I had to throw something together quickly without running to the store. I had no Tilapia on hand but had some Orange Roughy in the freezer. It has a little more moisture than the tilapia so it fell apart much easier when transferring to a serving dish, but the flavor was still delicious. I use fresh grated parmesan, which I think makes it more flavorful than the "powdered" stuff, and tonight I used fresh basil from my garden and I think it enhanced the flavor even more! Highly recommend for even the pickiest eaters.

text:
I have been making this recipe for a year now, and just realized I never rated it.  This is one of my favorite fish recipes of all time.  I add about 1/4 cup of Italian flavored breadcrumbs, and I also find that if you put the mixture in the refrigerator for about 15-20 minutes prior, it seems to spread on better to the hot fish.  My husband gobbles this down and he doesn't care for white fish at all. You will not be disappointed with this recipe.

text:
I used this mixture on extra large shrimp and it was devine. Just coated the shrimp, broiled for about 5 minutes and that's all. We cook a lot of shrimp so I was really happy to find this recipe for fish which I thought looked really good for shrimp. 

Also used tilapia the same meal with the same recipe. Did a little seafood night. 

If ya all try my suggestion of the shrimp  variation, please keep in mind that you should use shrimp with the shell off. Other wise all the yummy is getting thrown away with the shell. And you will not need to flip the shrimp over. They will cook in zoom time. 

I will also try this again on other fish.

Made as recipe states except I didn't have any celery salt so I omitted it, and I used a dash of onion flakes instead of onion powder (I didn't have any of that either).  They are both present in such small quantities I don't think it mattered.  My husband said it was really good, my little kid said it was okay, and my older kid didn't like it at all, and she generally gobbles up fish.  I hate fish, so I didn't even try it.  What I liked was that it was easy to make and didn't stink up the house, but all the butter in the topping made a pool of grease on the foil.  Ick.  FAR too much butter in this recipe.  And despite my husband liking the taste, none of us liked how it looked.  My kids saw it after I pulled it out of the oven and said "Gross!  What IS that?"  Sorry, but I won't be making this one again.

TASTY TASTY TASTY!!! My husband and I both really loved this.  

I did make a few changes: I used half of a shredded romano parmesan and half the fine parmesan cheese to make up the 1/2 cup required.  I added, as suggested by another reviewer, a 1/2 cup of seasoned bread crumbs as well.  I half melted some I Can't Believe... spread in place of the butter and used light miracle whip in place of the mayo to reduce calories and fat. I also minced a large clove of garlic and mixed it in with the mayo/butter/seasoning mix.  

I didn't have any celery salt, but figured with the bread crumbs being seasoned I really didn't need to add anything in place of it.  I did sprinkle a dash of salmon seasoning in with the basil, though.

It turned out great even without using real butter or mayo, which I was worried about. I used a previously frozen tilapia from a bag, so I think that caused a little bit of watery consistency under the fish.  But the fish was moist and flaky, and the topping was tangy and delish so it was still five stars for me.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-04-01T06:04:19.907
helpfulCount:
2

text:
Wow -who would have thought this could be so good? I modified as follows: seasoned raw fish with Old Bay before broiling; used fresh basil in the topping and served with basil chiffonade on a bed of rice; used panko in the topping which made it hold together better and brown really nicely. I had fresh walleye instead of tilapia, but this would work well with any flat, whitefish that's too thin to grill! Everybody raved and there wasn't a speck of food left. Easy AND a crowd pleaser, it doesn't get much better!

text:
Finally a recipe that makes tilapia actually taste good!  I have never been a fan of tilapia - I prefer more flavorful varieties like haddock, mahi mahi, sea bass, salmon... haddock (my favorite) is overfished so I try to avoid it.  This was very tasty and so quick and easy!  I used fresh filets (which I found to be VERY economical, btw!), fresh grated parmesan cheese and since I was too lazy to soften butter in the microwave I unscrewed the top of my butter flavor spray and poured out the right amount.  Also added garlic powder.   Very tasty, although with the parmesan it did have a salty aftertaste, so I'm thinking the celery salt is optional next time.  I will definitely make this again!

text:
The first time I made this for my family it was gone in minutes - everyone loved it!  I followed the recipe exactly.  The next time I made it I wanted to mix it up a bit, so before adding the butter-cheese-herb mixture on top of the fish I mixed in a handful of small scallops (since they are my hubby's favorite seafood) before spreading it on the fish - I didn't change the cooking times at all, and with just the 2-3 minutes under the broiler the last time it cooked the scallops perfectly, now they are a must everytime I make this!  (You could probably do it with baby shrimp as well...)

text:
AWESOME!!!  Finally a fish recipe that BOTH of my kids will eat!!  My 8yo daughter kept saying "mmmmm... I like this chicken".  LOL  So that says quite a bit for it's mildness.  :)  The thing to remember w/ tilapia (that I learned the hard way) is to make sure that none of your fish overlaps or touches the other pieces or it will have a very strong fishy taste -- at least that's what happened to some of mine the first time I ever cooked tilapia.  Only the parts that were touching or overlapping tasted that way, though.  The rest was the normal, yummy, mild tilapia.  GREAT RECIPE!!!!!!  A definite family fave!!!

text:
WOW!! This was simply DELICIOUS!! I was looking for a good tilapia recipe, besides the same old battered fried version. I scaled the recipe down to one so I could try it for lunch, I didn't have any lemon juice, onion powder, or celery salt, so I used my favorite lemon pepper, and a little italian herbs, and probably a little bit more butter because I was cooking it alongside some frozen broccoli pieces. It turned out very juicy, the buttery juice in the pan seasoned my broccoli, and served it with a piece of garlic bread. I also didn't have any parmesan cheese, so I used a little bit of 5 cheese italian. My husband, who hates fish, but makes the best fish I know, LOVED this recipe when I made it again for dinner! This time, I added some italian style bread crumbs, and some garlic powder. I will never eat tilapia any other way. Great job!
