text:
Wow, BELIEVE THE HYPE!  How could this be bad?  Parmesan, mayo and butter?!?!  SOOO delicious.  As the other reviews seem to say, this is a great base that you can season to your liking.  Like other users, I added 3 tablespoons of breadcrumbs and ended up not using celery salt.  I added dried parsley, garlic powder and a dash of hot sauce.  And I also seasoned the tilapia with seasoning salt before adding the topping.  I hate cooking fish because I’m always afraid of over/under cooking it, but I followed the instructions exactly and it was so yummy.  Thanks, Phoebe!

text:
This has really terrific flavor and comes out nicely browned on top.  I may add a little sprinkle of bread crumbs next time, though it doesn't need anything.  I did cut down on some of the butter since mayo has quite a bit of fat.  Didn't have celery salt.  I seasoned the fish and squirted with spray butter before 1st round of broiling. Didn't need to flip, cooked fine.

Spectacular base recipe to play with - thanks!

country:
None
text:
OMG this dish is AWESOME!!!!  I have a three-year-old and a six-year-old son and they both gave it 5 stars!!  I kind of took some liberties with the recipe.  I sprinkled a "meat tenderiser" on first and broiled for long enough to dig out the rest of the ingredients.  I combined the recommended amount of parmesan with a Tbs of store bought minced garlic and some basil and Italian spices and the mayo (which was fat free), and Promise fat free spread intead of butter. This mixture would be amazing on any fish but is especially delicious on the delicately flavored tilapia.  PLEASE TRY!

text:
Good recipe - very flavorful.  I think next time I may substitute dill for the basil.  Basil is kind of an unusual spice with fish.  But overall, very good.  Also, I added some fresh diced Roma tomatoes for color, texture and a hint of flavor.  Additional additions and substitutions: lowfat mayo for regular, added just a pinch of dill, substituted seasoning salt for celery salt, added a bit more garlic powder.  (As I said before though, I think I'll leave the basil out altogether and use the dill.)  I served this with corn on the cob, garlic butter bread and fresh green beans.

text:
I made this fish for dinner tonight and followed the recipe exactly and in the end, we thought it was just ok.  The plus side is that it was a very quick dish to throw together with a very quick cook time.  The minus is that the parmesan "spread" overpowers the flavour of the fish.  The bottom line for us is that if you like the flavour of fish, try a little less topping.

text:
Quite Tasty!  I HATE fish but bought some tilapia because I know it's good for you.  This recipe was just what I needed!  I cut the recipe to 2 servings and used most of the sauce on one tilapia filet.  I used canned parmesan (sprinkle cheese) and bottled lemon juice because that's what I had on hand.  I also subbed garlic powder for the celery salt because I don't like celery and it didn't need any additional salt.  I served it with couscous and a green salad.  Thanks for helping me eat quick and healthy!

EDIT: 01/28/2009:  This is one of my most frequently used recipes from this site.  I have done all kinds of variations on this recipe.  Our fave so far was to add a dash or two of cayenne for kick.  Thanks again for a great recipe!

text:
YUM!!  Quick and easy and delicious!  What more could a working mom ask for?!?  It's not 'fishy' so anyone will like this.  I subbed garlic powder for the celery salt (personal preference) and this was 'rock my socks' good!  Thanks!! UPDATE!  6/4/07  I used some old bay seasoning on the filets before I broiled them.  I also added some (a little dash) cayenne pepper and about 1/8 cup of panko bread crumbs.  Next time, I'm going to cut the lemon juice a little and add about 1/4 cup panko - oh yeah, I added a little paprika for color.  This is a recipe I'd serve to my mom- certified fish hater (except for classic fish n chips) and think she'd like.  Thanks for a classic!!

I am definitely not a big fan of fish, but this recipe has made eating fish enjoyable.  My husband, who does like fish, said this was the best fish he ever had. This was the first time that we ever used our broiler, and besides setting off the fire alarm in our kitchen (we like things well done), I am planning on cooking with this recipe again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!!  Very quick, easy and all of the ingredients (except the fish!) were readily on hand. (I love when I don't have to shop for special ingredients!)   It was the first time I cooked Tilapia (I used fresh), and my husband says this is now is most favorite fish dish, and he especially loved the flavor of the sauce.  I, too, used garlic salt instead of celery salt, as I thought I'd like the flavor better.  And, since I usually don't take the time to measure quantities, I suspect I used a little more of the spices than called for.  I did not have any lemons on hand for "fresh" lemon juice, so I used reconstituted lemon juice.  Also, I spread 1 tablespoon of the 3 tablespoons of mayo called for on top of the fish before putting it under the broiler, and then just mixed the remaining 2 TBLSP in with the cheese mixture.  The fish was sooooo moist and yummy.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Delicious as is but I made a few changes. I cut the recipe in half for 3 fillets. It made enough to coat both front and back of the fish. I added a 1/4 cup seasoned bread crumbs, 1 1/2 tablespoon mascarpone cheese (because I had it in the fridge) basil pesto for the dried basil (also because I had it in the fridge) 1/4 tsp smoked paprika, 1/8 tsp garlic powder, a pinch of red pepper flakes, 1/8 tsp salt, 1/8 tsp celery seed, a light sprinkle of poultry seasoning and a light squeeze of fresh lemon juice! I seasoned the tilapia with seasoned salt and freshly ground pepper and a light squeeze of fresh lemon juice over the fillets. Followed the rest of the recipe on broiling it and that's it! It was DELICIOUS!! My family raved! Both my husband and mother in law's first expressing was, "this is delicious!" and even my 3 year old gobbled this up! Served this with coconut rice and Parmesean broccoli.

I grew up never eating fish, ever. We ate a lot of take in my house growing up. As I've gotten older I've really tried to bring some new things into my home for my family, so my kids won't have the same eating problems I do. This was my very first fish dish. I was nervous and I'd never ever worked with fish or even thought I could cook it. This came out so great everyone cleaned their plates! No leftovers which means mission accomplished mom! The only thing I would say is handle the fish with care because it falls apart pretty easy, I'm sure everyone else already knows that though.  The flavor on it was kind of tangy and cheesy which everyone really loved. Thanks so much for this great recipe I'm adding it to my dinner arsenal. It was super easy for me, a beginner, to make and the end result made me feel really good. Thanks again!

region:

country:

text:
My boyfriend and I really enjoyed this. It was my first time broiling fish and first time cooking tilapia - and I will definitely be making this again! I rarely am satisfied with something the first time cooking it, and this was perfect as is. I followed the recipe exactly except added a little paprika as others suggested. I was making it for 2 so I cut the cheese mixture in half which made enough to smother two large fillets. I broiled on the highest rack in my oven - 2 minutes, flipped, 2 minutes, removed to add topping and cooked 3.5 more minutes. The top was a nice golden brown color when finished.

Served with Mushroom Orzo (on this site) and pan-fried okra (just cook with olive oil and season liberally with Tony Chachere's for about 15 minutes on medium-high heat).

text:
This is really deliciously and can be easily made much lower in calories with low fat mayonnaise. (I like Best Foods version).   I also agree with the other reviewers that some Old Bay seasoning or your favorite seasoning is a must.   Somewhat bland without it.   I didn't bother with flipping the fillets at all.   Just pulled them a little further away from the broiler burner and let this cook for 5-6 minutes on one side before adding the mayo/butter/cheese mix.   Overall, this recipe is fast, it's easy, it can be low cal -- I LOVE IT!

text:
I was looking for an easy recipe, and wow, this recipe exceeded my expectations! I didn't use the celery salt and used garlic versus onion powder. I also took the advice off another user and added Panko bread crumbs to keep the topping in place. A bit more parmesan cheese was used since I had more than 2lbs of fish. Used fresh basil versus dry, and it was the best tilapia my whole family ever had! So glad and happy this website exists! Thanks for a delicious meal!

text:
I was skeptical when I saw cheese and fish, but I was very pleasantly surprised at how amazing this tasted! I make a smaller version for one filet at a time. I added about 1/4 cup pano bread crumbs to the cheese mixture and then sprinkled some on top of the filet covered in the cheese mixture. The filet is soft so this gave it the perfect amount of crunch. Depending on your oven, you may want to stay on the short side of the 2-3 minute per side range.

Satisfied 8 of the pickiest eaters, from 7 yrs old to 76 yrs young. Everyone cleaned their plates & even asked for me to make it again. Recipe is little light on the lemon juice for some so I just put a bowl on the table & folks added as they pleased. I put mixture on both sides of fish. Fantastic flavour!

I made this with Basa fish, since that is what I had on hand, and the butter, parmesan, and lemon mixture was wonderful!

I did have to pretty much double the cooking times, since my fish was still half frozen, and I think my Basa filets may be thicker than the Tilapia would have been. However, it still came out beautifully!

I have a feeling I'm going to be eating fish more often!

text:
Made this tonight and everyone loved it! Said it tasted better than a restaurant dish. The only things I did differently was rubbed the fish with a little oil and sprinkled a little lemon pepper seasoning on the tilapia before I broiled it. Also, I omitted the lemon juice from topping since I added the lemon pepper seasoning and instead of basil, onion powder and celery salt I used salt, pepper and garlic powder in the topping.  I can't believe how quick and easy this was and it tasted so good! This will added to our regular rotation.

I loved this! I used celery seed instead of salt as I had it on hand.  My mayo is light. After reading other reviews, I added 1/2 c  breadcrumbs to mixture. It stayed on nicely. text:
It was really good - has tons of possibilities for customization.  I didn't have lemons, but used lemon pepper. Didn't have onion powder, but added garlic powder.  I do recommend seasoning the fish first though (some reviewers mention Old Bay), as the fish without the topping was kind of bland. I also only had one tilapia filet, so I added a pile of frozen shrimp next to the fish and topped that with the Parmesan topping.  It was really good too. I can imagine putting it on scallops or any seafood would work just as well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this recipe 4 stars because I made a couple of small modifications to it. Instead of mayo I used 1/2 cup plain Fage Greek yogurt, a tbsp of butter, and the juice of one whole lemon. We don't use mayo at our house and plain Greek yogurt is MUCH healthier. I also opted for garlic salt instead of celery salt. I kept all other ingredients and amounts the same. I broil on second rack from the top for the first few minutes then after topping with the mixture I move the broiling pan to the first rack to brown the topping. Serve with a wild/brown rice mixture and some steamed veggies. This makes one healthier, delicious, and easy meal.

text:
This recipe was perfect after I changed one thing. The butter is totally not needed, otherwise the sauce slides right off the tilapia. I make the sauce and store it in a jar in my fridge and spoon out what I need as I need it. The flavor is absolutely beautiful My husband and I love to serve this over a bed of rice so we can savor every last bit of sauce. You can totally get away with using a lite or olive oil mayonnaise in this because there is so much other flavor it will not be noticed.

text:
LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this recipe!  It's quick, it's easy and it tastes awesome!  I followed the recipe exactly with the exception of lightly sprinkling the fillets with garlic salt on both sides but next time will only sprinkle one side or use just garlic powder.  Also, I broiled 3 minutes on each side (instead of 2 minutes) plus another 3 minutes after putting on the topping and the fish was not at all overcooked; it was tender and moist.  I served with steamed broccoli florets and Hidden Valley Ranch roasted potatoes.  When I was preparing this meal I wasn't too sure if the ranch flavor of the potatoes and the flavors from the cheese coating would go together but it did...everyone loved the entire meal!

text:
I don't usually make fish because I end up over cooking or under seasoning it but this dish was super easy to make. I am not a mayonnaise fan at all but it was more cheesy than mayo so I enjoyed it. 

Obviously you can substitute out any white flaky fish that is on sale for the tilapia.

This is an easy recipe and REALLY good too.

The second time I made this dish I doubled the quantity and put it in a dish instead of on a pan and omitted the tilapia all together(took about 5 minutes to brown). I then mixed it with 12oz of cooked bow tie pasta. it is delicious!

The reason I did not add the fish is my girlfriend is pregnant, and the smell of fish makes her sick. next time I will add chicken to it... I can't wait to try that!

This was so good and super easy. I did as one of the other reviewers mentioned and added about 1/3 c. bread crumbs, 1/2 tsp. paprika and 1/2 tsp. red pepper flakes. My 8 yr. old, a picky eater, also liked this and my husband and I loved it. Definitely a keeper and even company worthy.

text:
I used regular salt because I didn't have celery salt, and only made enough for one serving (I premake my lunches and dinners for the day due to my work schedule.) When it came out of the oven it looked and smelt delicious, but I didn't eat it until 8 hours later after I reheated it in the microwave from the fridge. 
It did NOT taste good when reheat. I want to try to make this again, but eat it right away next time, perhaps it will be better. I think I over cooked the fish accidently, so this warning "Be careful not to over cook the fish." from step 3, VERY IMPORTANT!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used Swai fish.  The only changes that I made to the recipe was I added 3/4c. Panko crumbs to the mixture.  I cooked the fish without flipping it.  I broiled mine until completely done, and then, pressed the crumb mixture onto each fish, and returned it to the broiler.  At this point, watch it very closely!  It gets brown very quickly; less than 3 mins.  Hubby and son liked it and said they would eat it again.  I think next time, I will try the tilapia or even an orange roughy.  Yummo!

This fish came out really good, but I can only give it four stars because I changed it so much. I seasoned the fish with what it called for but added some garlic powder and replaced black pepper with lemon pepper. from there I broiled as it said. I added apex. 3/4 c of bread crumbs to the cheese and melted the butter before adding it to crumb mixture. I brushed the fish with the Mayo. Adding the crumb mixture on top and broiling it again to brown the topping. Entire family enjoyed it. And it was not soggy like other reviews stated it would get.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe.  My roomate, who does not particularly like fish, kept telling me how much she liked it and said I could make this any time!  
I did not have celery salt or basil.  Instead, added two cloves of crushed garlic and a bit of garlic salt, as well as two teaspoons of dried Italian seasing. I also did not have plain parmesan so used a four cheese Italian blend.   Followed another reviewer's advice and added bread brumbs to the mixture after the original mixture started to slide from the hot fish.  This is a keeper!

text:
This was absolutely DELICIOUS!!!  My very, VERY, VERY picky 7 year old daughter told me it was so good and she felt like she was in a restaurant :-) and it looked like restaurant food.  I have to say I was impressed with the way it came out as well.  I did read a lot of the reviews an received a lot of helpful tips such as....spray the pan and the fish with vegetable cooking spray, I used EVOO in place of the butter, I didn't have celery salt so I used garlic salt, and I added bread crumbs on top of the cheese mixture. I saw a lot of ppl changed the lemon juice and used limes instead, but I actually loved the taste of the lemon juice.  This will definitely be added into my meal rotation!!  Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
I loved this recipe! I am a true cooking newbie and I generally don't like fish, but my boyfriend has been craving fish lately so I decided to make this dish for him (he doesn't know how much a cooking rookie I am!).  I substituted garlic powder for the celery salt since I didn't have any, and I also added 1/4 teaspoon of cayenne pepper for a little kick.  It was super fast and easy and DELICIOUS! I ate two fillets by myself and my boyfriend told me what an awesome cook I was! Thanks for this great recipe!

Very good & easy to make. The only thing I would like to say is it takes more than 2 minutes to broil the fish, maybe 4-5, i just kept an eye on the fish so it won't over cook. This dish is super. It's hard not to deviate from the recipe but this one does not need it. It's a keeper

text:
Hands down, one of my favorite recipes EVER!  I modified the recipe only slightly by adding 1/8 tsp. garlic powder and 1/8 tsp. paprika.  Also, I cook the fish in 3-minute intervals, for a total of 9 minutes cooking time.

What I love about this recipe is the very short prep time (no chopping of anything) and the rapid cook time.  Best of all, I am love with the incredible flavor!  In my opinion, it is a restaurant-quality flavor.  Absolutely delicious!  Never any leftovers with this dish!  Enjoy!

text:
Made this tonight, everyone loved it!  I read the reviews and made a few adjustments based on the recommendations.  I sprinkled the fillets with Old Bay on both sides before cooking, and also cut the amount of butter to just less than half (about two tablespoons), and it was plenty.  I didn't have a problem with the cheese mixture sliding off...there was a reviewer who mentioned that, but I left my mixture at room temperature until using it, so maybe that makes the difference.  My husband has already asked me to make it again soon, thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This is an AMAZING recipe! I followed some of the others advice-I added garlic powder and a little spice, and broiled on one side, then when flipping, added the mixture on top. It's even better when it is a bit browned, and tilapia cooks so fast. I don't like mayo, but wanted to follow the recipe straight the first time, but you don't taste the mayo at all. It acts as more of a "moisturizer' for the fish. I am interested trying a little cream cheese instead next time. EXCELLENT-try this!

text:
This is a fantastic recipe with one modification: add Panko bread crumbs to the topping mixture; it gives the fish a nice crunch and beefs up the topping so it doesn't run off the fish when broiled. I made it the first time as written; husband said it had good flavor but didn't like the mouthfeel. Made it a second time with the addition of Panko and it put this one over the top. We LOVED it. I think this would be good with the addition of chopped artichoke hearts as another reviewer suggested. Next time!

text:
I've made this recipe twice now and my picky eater toddler seems to eat tilapia only if it is cooked this way.  A few modifications I made the second time around:  I used light ranch instead of mayonaise and thus, removed fresh lemon juice from the original recipe.  I also added 1/4 teaspoon of paprika and garlic powder.  Instead of celery salt I use soul food seasoning salt and I also add 2 teaspoons of balsamic vinegar.  It came out very tasty the second time around.

text:
Wow, even I loved this, and I don't like fish!  I made exactly as stated.  I had bought a bag of frozen tilapia from Costco.  Each piece of fish is individually wrapped.  I didn't thaw the fish. I put the frozen fish on the broiler pan, which I had covered with tin foil and nonstick spray. I did salt the fish a bit with kosher salt before using the parmesan mixture. It had to broil a few minutes longer because of it being frozen. The fish was flaky and mild and delicious!

text:
Excellent recipe! I made this last night for the first time and the family loved it so much, it is getting saved for frequent use. I basically followed it, except I didn't measure out the basil, pepper and onion powder. I also didn't use celery salt, but celery seed instead. I just sprinkled the seasoning over each fillet, flipped them and sprinkled it again. I think doing it that way I used more than what the recipe called for, but it was VERY tasty and salt free, except for the mayo I suppose. The Parmesan sauce was excellent and I followed that exact. It smelled amazing when I took it out. We don't like fish, so this says a lot. Finally a fish recipe that we can all enjoy! Thanks for sharing Phoebe.

text:
This was delicious and so easy...but only giving 4 stars because when broiled as directed, the fish was not cooked!  Maybe because the fillets were still partly frozen...anyway I turned the oven up to 400 and put them back in for 15 minutes and they were thoroughly cooked.  Next time I make this, i will bake the fillets first and then broil with the topping.  I also added some extra seasonings (paprika, garlic powder, red pepper flakes), panko bread crumbs and seasoned the fillets with Old Bay.  I loved how easy this recipe was!

text:
This has become my new standard way of making tilapia. I use seasoned salt on top of the mayo mix. I just sprinkle it on top. I don't even worry about mixing it into the mayo mix. Also, start by placing the side you want up, face down so that after you flip, you have most presentable side showing.

text:
One of the best Tilapia recipes we've tried!  Cut recipe in half for 1lb of fish.  Followed the recipe closely but used 1TBS of butter and then olive oil, celery seed and garlic salt plus the other recommended seasonings, then added about 1/4C Panko bread crumbs which kept the sauce on the fish.  Sprayed fish with a little olive oil when I turned them over.  Delicious recipe for the regular rotation!

dateLastModified:

userID:
2448319
Display Name:
Holiday Baker
isPro:

839

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2368134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good for a baked/broiled fish. I used the calculate button on the recipe page and changed the recipe to 4 servings instead of 8, because there was just 2 of us eating. The recommended broiling times per side is 2-3 minutes. My fillets were a little thick and I did 5 minutes per side. Next time I might change that to 6 minutes. I would just keep an eye on it. I also used lite mayo, because it was what I had on hand. The fish tastes pretty good out of the oven. But, I found that it does not re-heat well the next day in the microwave. It gets a little dry and the sauce basically disappears. It also gets very fishy tasting re-heated. So, I would make only what you need the night you make it.

Will add to the rotation.  Thank you for sharing.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish was very salty in our opinion.  Parmesean is a salty variety of cheese to begin with, and I think the addition of celery salt puts this recipe in the "too salty" category.  I'm not sure I'll try it again, but if I do, I'll use a bit of celery seed instead of celery salt.  I would also suggest using unsalted butter.  If you are going to use Old Bay as recommended by others, use sparingly because it adds to the salty factor!  The cooking time on the fish was perfect as written.

I've made this recipe three times now and its definitely a keeper. My only thing is -Make sure you cook the fish before putting the sauce on. text:
This was a pretty decent recipe. I made some minor changes--used sour cream instead of mayo because I hate mayo; used garlic powder and regular salt instead of celery salt, per some reviews; and sprinkled a bit of old bay seasoning on the fillets before broiling, also per some reviews. The taste was pleasing, but not particularly strong, but I think that's my fault. I will definitely try this again, next time adding more garlic powder, and adding more than a "sprinkle" of old bay seasoning right into the parm mix. I think those small adjustments could kick my rating to a 4 or even a 5. FYI, i served with spinach-ricotta tortellini as a side dish--made a great combo!

This recipe was very tasty.  I rated it four stars rather than five simply because it is just so very salty. I would highly recommend omitting the celery salt altogether and even using unsalted butter to cut back on the salt, since Parmesan is already so very, very salty. Other than that, we really enjoyed this nice strong flavor to accompany a mild fish.

Delicious!!  We'll be making this one again for sure!  I did make some changes suggested by others. text:
I have made this recipe several times and it's always a hit.  Although we prefer it made with the fish, if you are not a fish lover, you can substitue skinless, boneless, chicken breasts.  They will take a little longer to broil, depending on the thickness.  I sliced the breasts into thinner slices to help them broil more evenly.

text:
Made this for the hubby for dinner and it was yummy!  I broiled the fish 3 min on one side and then a total of 7 min on the other side.  The fish came out perfectly flaky but the topping never browned.  I think because I reduced the recipe to just 2 servings, it didn't translate very well.  Next time I will reduce the mayo by at least half and see how that works because the topping seemed runny.  I'll also try what some other reviewers did and broil it with the topping on it from the beginning and not worry about flipping.  But no matter what  troubles I had, this will definitely be something I'll make again.  The combination of flavors was fantastic!

text:
I love this recipe.  It's delicious, but it's also healthy and so easy that my 11 year old son can make it and feel awesome because he cooked supper.  That said, we do make some changes to suit our tastes:  we cut way back on the mayo and use fresh basil instead of dried if we've got it.  We also don't use celery salt.  I think next time I make it, I'm going to use pecorino cheese instead of parmesan.  One last thing- we always sprinkle the filets lightly with Old Bay or cayenne before we toss them in the oven.  If you haven't tried this yet, you really should.

I made a slight adjustment to the recipe to hopefully get my very picky son to eat it.  He loved it!  I melted the butter w/the lemon juice, mixed in the mayo and added the seasonings and cheese to 1 1/2 of bread crumbs.  dipped fish in butter mixture, rolled in bread crumb mixture, baked at 350 for 15 minutes and broiled until browned.  It was a hit!

I was looking for a recipe to use up some tilapia filets we had bought from Walmart and came across this. I had everything but the lemon juice and it was fine without it. This dish is company worthy and it only takes a short time to prepare! Thanks Phoebe!

text:
Excellent dish.  The key is to cook the tilapia just before the coating is about to burn.  I followed the step to a T, and then popped it back in the oven at 1 minute intervals about 4 or 5 times, checking the flakiness each time.  The dark brown (near burnt) coating coincided with the fish being cooked perfectly.

text:
This recipe is a keeper!  Modifications:  * instead of onion powder, I used garlic powder * instead of celery salt, I used seasoned salt * also used Old Bay on the fish as well as in the mixture * added cayenne pepper to the fish * squeezed the remaining lemon onto the fish prior to putting the cheese mixture on  As other reviewers have mentioned, the cheese mixture makes more than enough for 2 pounds of fish. (Not that I'm complaining!)  It took about 8 minutes to cook and get the cheese nice & bubbly.  I served this tilapia with home fried potatoes and steamed broccoli.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/46.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my family's all time FAVOURITE way to eat fish! It is extremely fast and easy. I make the cheese mixture earlier, and let the flavours 'set' in the fridge for the day. The cheese mixture starts to melt when you put it on the fish, so I remove it from the fridge just before putting it on the fish. This helps to keep it 'on' the fish, and not running onto the baking pan (although if any does run onto the pan, we make sure to scrape it up and put it back on the fish just before serving... it's THAT good!). Thanks Phoebe!

This was delicious. I got "the look" from my husband when he took his first bite! As others had advised, I added a touch of Old Bay and bread crumbs. I broiled on low for two minutes on one side (I had VERY thin fillets), and two minutes on the other, then added topping for three or until it was good and browned. It took longer to make the side dishes than the fish!

text:
I hate fish. However, my husband does not, and I love him so much I was willing to take one for the team and try this recipe out. The outcome...I still hate fish. BUT, if I did like fish, I would eat it like this. The cheese dressing was delicious. My husband really liked it. I think anyone who enjoys eating fish will like this recipe. And anyone who does not, will enjoy scrapping off the topping like I did. I did omit the lemon juice and I added garlic powder as I would put that on ice cream if I could. All in all, this is easy, quick, and worth a shot. The only down side is...it's fish.

text:
Awesome recipe!!!  I followed someones advice to add bread crumbs to the topping and it was a great idea.  I made it the first time with the bread crumbs and the topping stayed on top perfectly but the second time I forgot them and it all melted off the fish.  It took me a minute to figure out what happened.  I will always use the bread crumbs from now on.  I also added about 1/4 tsp. paprika and everything was wonderful!!  This is a keeper!!

text:
I skipped the lemon (didn't have any) and celery salt, but even without these it was delicious. I also added bay seasoning. Mayo is the secret here as that's how I always cook my fish in the oven whether it's tilapia, salmon, cod, etc. It helps get rid of some of the really fishy taste that comes with store bought fish, even if you spread just a thin layer on. Loved the taste of the parmesan with it. Will definitely be making this often since tilapia is one of my favorites.

text:
This was delicious! I used 3 tilapia fillets, and used 2 T smart balance/reduced fat butter, about 1/3 C parmesan, and added some garlic powder and about 1/4 C flavored bread crumbs. I skipped the celery salt.  I broiled the fillets for about 8 minutes on one side before adding the topping, which was on for about another 5 minutes.  I didn't flip the fish.  This was great, Thanks Phoebe!

text:
This is surprisingly good, my family liked it so much I made it twice! I eye balled the amounts, used fat free sour cream one time & plain yogurt the other time and about the same spices plus paprika and it came out well both times. I only did 5 min one side, flipped and spread the topping and broiled another 5. I disagree with the person who said it was too pungent. I think the creamyness of the spread compliments the buttery tilapia and the aged parmesan. I'm going to try this with other whitefish.

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
3532698
Display Name:
HeismyHope
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
15
favoritesCount:
69
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! Here is what I did. I always have frozen tilapia fillets in the freezer (fish is actually a better quality when it is frozen). I had 5 fillets and I put them on a foil lined pan.  Sprinkled the frozen fillets with old bay and put them under the broiler until they were no longer frozen.  To the spread I added a handful of breadcrumbs, olive oil mayo, old bay, garlic salt, and dried chopped onion.  I did not use the lemon, basil, onion powder, or celery salt.  The cheese I used was a blend of asiago, parmesan, and romano. I spread a heaping tsp of that on the fillets then sprinkled a little bit more cheese and breadcrumbs for a crust.  Then put it under the broiler until it was nice and golden brown.  I knew I would have extra spread so I bought white mushrooms (about 12) and stuffed those with the spread and put those under the broiler.  The stuffed mushroom idea came from another reviewer. This was an amazing recipe.  The stuffed mushrooms and fish tasted like they were from the restaurant.

text:
I actually give it 4.5 stars.  I added a bit more onion powder, some garlic powder, and Old Bay Seasoning.  I had to bake the fish a little longer because I think I added a little too much topping and it took a little longer to brown.  I also topped off with a little more parmesan.  Otherwise, my husband and I loved it.  He loved it so much that I ended up buying a bulk package of frozen tilapia so we can enjoy it again and again :)  I served it with some white rice with basil and garlic and blanched broccoli with freshly ground black pepper.  Very tasty!

None
text:
This recipe was very easy to prepare and had wonderful flavor. Definitely a repeat. Like others, I made a few modifications: 1) to lighten the fat a bit, I used light mayonnaise and Smart Balance. Also, I used fresh basil rather than dried. 2) spray the foil and the Tilapia with olive oil. 2) sprinkle fish with garlic and pepper 3) broil 3 minutes (vein side down). 4) spread Parmesan/mayo/butter/basil mixture over fish. 5) broil 3 more minutes, watching closely until topping is lightly browned.

country:
None
text:
This fish is AMAZING! Unfortunately, I did not have a broiling pan, or celery salt. I reduced the serving size down to 2, and added 1/8th tsp garlic, and red pepper flakes.  I then followed directions except I heated a pan on the stove at medium heat with spray canola oil lightly covering the pan. I cooked the fish for approx. 3 min on each side until it was white and almost completely cooked.   I then applied the ingredient paste over the fish, cooked for 1 minute, then flipped the fish, reapplied ingredient paste, and cooked for another minute.   BEST MEAL IN YEARS! BEST PARMESAN EVER!  I may have slightly overcooked the fish, but I couldn't tell a difference.

text:
Just got done eating this and made a few tweeks of my own. I didn't have celery salt or onion powder, but I did add the garlic powder, red pepper flakes, bread crumbs and paprika that another user suggested. I also used low fat mayo and margarine. The only thing that didn't work for me was coating the fish in the breading. I found that after broiling the fish for three minutes, the mixture would not stick to the fish so I didn't get an all over crispy topping as I was hoping for. It did taste great, though!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used reduced fat parmesan, light mayo, and Brummel and Brown for the butter and only 1 T lemon juice. I didn't have any celery salt, increased the black pepper to probably 1 t, and used 1/4 t seasoned salt. After I sprinkled the herbs on the fish, I sprayed each fillet with cooking spray.  Broiled for 4 minutes and didn't flip it. Added the coating on top of each fillet (I had 3 fillets, but there was enough coating for at least 4 more) and broiled on second rack from the top for 2 minutes on high.  The fish was perfectly moist. The flavor was great. I will use this many more times and will try it on other white fish fillets!

text:
Delish! I was looking for something fast, easy and delicious for my tilapia and this recipe had it all. The only substitutions I made were romano for the parmesan and garlic powder for the onion powder since that's what I had on hand. I didn't get the cheesy looking crust like in the photo that I was expecting. Mine came out more like a sauce. So I think next time I make this (and I will definitely make this again) I will either add more cheese or maybe some breadcrumbs to keep it on top of the fish.

text:
This was great. I am not sure how closely I followed the recipe, since I was scaling it for just two pieces of fish.  I did use all the ingredients, just probably not in the right amounts. I was apprehensive about using too much mayo, so I only used a little bit but I really couldn't taste it at all and I probably could have spread the topping more easily with more in there. I served it atop the Orzo Alfredo recipe from this site, with roasted garlic and a baguette on the side. I also managed to use my broiler without burning the food, so that was a major success. I think next time though I will put some dry seasonings on both sides of the fish before adding the topping to give it a little more flavor. Very easy meal and I'm looking forward to having it again. Boyfriend liked it too.

text:
Absolutely the most delicious fish preparation ever! Foolproof, too. I found this recipe the way I do a lot of excellent recipes on this site: I searched under the food I wanted to prepare (tilapia) then sorted the hundreds of results by rating, and read the top rated ones. This was extremely highly rated, and after making it several times, I know why. Not only is it delicious, it is extremely accomodating in terms of the exact quantities/proportions of the mayo, butter and parm you put in. It cooks quickly, so definitely watch it and don't let it overcook! Even my non fish-loving 9 and 12 year old sons loved this recipe.

text:
This recipe is excellent - IF you are not looking for a big fishy taste.  We make it quite often as it's a great way to prepare fish for those who are not huge fish fans.  I add bread crumbs to the top (helps hold the topping in place) and usually pair with garlic mashed potatoes.  You can save the left over hopping and put on top of plain mashed potatoes to give them a creamy, garlicky taste.  Huge hit in my family!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this for over seven years now and LOVE it! I double the topping, add 2tsp of dill relish, and 1/4c of crushed butter crackers to the mixture right before spreading on the fish. It gives it texture and color as it broils. I also put the topping on raw fish and broil on low for about 5-7 minutes. Easier than flipping partially cooked fish and trying to spread on it. I serve this with orzo with fresh spinach, chopped tomatoes and cheese mixed in and a side of broccoli.

This earned rave reviews from my dinner companion!  I did have to make a couple of changes: I had fresh lime, but no lemon juice, so I squeezed some lime into the mix instead of measuring. I also cut the butter in half (next time, I may omit it since Tilapia is so naturally greasy), and I didn't have any celery salt, so I added a dash of table salt.  I'll make this again and stick with lime instead of lemon. It's a good fast & fancy main course.

I really wished it turned out better. I seasoned the sides of the fish with garlic salt and paprika before slathering on the cheese and breadcrumb mixture for the third broil.  My fiance said that the flavor was good, but there was too much topping so he ended up scraping some of it off his fish.  I might try this one again with the mayo, but I think I'll stick to panfrying my tilapia seasoned with adobo and paprika.

text:
Oh my gosh, oh my gosh, oh my gosh...this is excellent.  I did make a couple of changes, just because of what I had on hand and other viewers comments. Here are my changes...I reduced the butter by half, added 2 T. of light Ranch dressing, 1 tsp. red pepper,1 tsp. paprika and 2 T. fresh parsley, doubled the black pepper and chopped up 2 T. of red onion as I didn't have onion powder.  I also added 2 pressed garlic cloves.  I omitted the basil..just didn't have it on hand and added 1/4 C. of italian bread crumbs.  I followed the baking directions exactly.  This was out of the world delicious...tender, rich and tasty.  Be sure not to overcook the fish...it melts right in your mouth when cooked correctly!  I don't think you can go wrong with this recipe as long as you keep the base...mayo, butter, parm cheese and some seasonings.  SO quick and so easy.

text:
This was the best tilapia that I have ever tastes. Most of the time it has a fishy taste to it, but this was wonderful. My roommates requested it again the next day!  There is nothing that I would change about this recipe.  I read the reviews insisting on adding bread crumbs to thicken the mixture so it wouldn't fall off of the fish, but I didn't use bread crumbs nor did my mixture fall off of the fish.  I'm assuming the bread crumbs are for cosmetic reasons so that it can have that browning affect.

Again, BEST TILAPIA!!!!!

text:
Tilapia is such a mild fish that I am always looking for ways to jazz it up. This was a pretty good recipe that has plenty of room for adjustments or additions. Instead of mayo I used a vidalia onion cucumber-dill salad dressing that I discovered in the produce aisle. I also threw in some lemon juice and parmesan cheese but nothing else since the dressing is seasoned. Yummy!! Next time I would do the same but add bread crumbs for a little crunch. No more boring tilapia!

This was a very quick & easy recipe.  The overall taste is good, but like others suggested adding some breadcrumbs and fresh chopped parsley really helps bring up a notch.  Also I highly recommend seasoning the fish before broiling.  I just sprinkled on some S&P, but even then it was slightly bland. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have bread crumbs on hand, so I crumbled vegetable-flavored Ritz crackers and used that with the topping and it turned out fine. The parmesan is a nice touch and doesn't taste too cheesy....the flavor lends something subtle that's unplaceable but needed. I put a little bit of soy sauce in the bottom of the pan before broiling. If you're using large, thick filets, it can be difficult to flip them, especially without breaking the fish.

This was overall a decent recipe, but if you use full-fat mayo, beware: you'll only be able to eat half of your portion before it gets too rich. I might make it again, but overall, my household's impression was that it was just okay.

text:
So GOOD! I *hate* fish, but I loved this so much! I added some Tony Chachere's Creole Seasoning before baking and added a small pressed garlic clove to the topping mixture along with some bread crumbs and chopped fresh basil (I didn't have dried) and also skipped the onion powder, celery salt and black pepper (also didn't have any). I saved some parm and fresh basil for garnish. It was superb, a little tart, but perfect in my opinion to make it taste less "fishy". My BIL of few words even said "Nice!" when he ate it!

text:
This recipe is a family favorite for fish.  It's good enough as written to have once a week.  Sometimes I like to change it up but I mostly stick with the original.  It''s such a light tasting and flavorful dish.  Very quick to make on a hectic busy night.  I always have leftover mixture, so I store it in my fridge in a vacuumed-sealed half-pint jar making it an even faster weeknight meal.  I line my pan with foil for easy cleanup and broil on high for the recommended time.  I serve it with flavored rice and roasted asparagus. Yummy! Yummy! Yummy!

text:
The flavor of the celery salt/seed (we use seed) goes wonderfully with the tilapia.  Be sure to only soften the butter, not melt it.  (melted butter will cause the sauce to be runnier than you want).  Also, grated parmesan is actually better than shredded for consistency and flavor in this dish.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
What can I say?  This is the best recipe I have had for Tilapia.  I cooked it for my family and wow was it good.  I didn't make changes but I did use some of my own techniques. I added some Cajun to it, seasoning salt.  I also added more butter, a little less mayonnaise.  Also I used more paramesean cheese, maybe 1/4 cup more.  More butter to get it thinner of a sauce.  When I cooked the fish I put a dab of oil on the bottom of the pan, (GOOD OLIVE OIL).  3 MINUTES ON EACH SIDE IT GOOD ENOUGH.  Then another 3 minutes, with the sauce at the end.  I also pre seasoned the fish with Seasoning Salt before cooking it.  The flavor on this fish just erupted in the pan.  MMM MMM Good.

Very easy to make for such a tasty result! There's plenty of flavor and it's not a very expensive dinner, either. There was barely enough topping to go around, though, so I'd probably put a little extra of everything in next time so I can generously cover each filet. Careful when broiling, too, one of my filets was pretty thick and didn't cook through the first round, so I left it in for another couple minutes and it started smoking pretty badly. Still tasted good, though.

Very easy and tasty. I pretty much follow the recipe exact. Having read some of the other reviews I do add a touch of bread crumb to make the topping slightly thicker and that helps keep it in place. Once it starts cooking the topping has a tendency to "slip" off. So that helps. I have made this numerous times and it turns out great each time. Very good.

text:
My husband, as expected, peeked over my shoulder and wrinkled his nose.  "Mayonnaise? You're ruining the fish."  I thwapped him with a wooden spoon and chased him out of the kitchen, because I knew he'd like it, and he did.  This is going to become a family favorite, I can tell already, and we're not all that big on fish.  The topping is absolutely fantastic, and tilapia is unfishy enough that it's just delicious, even for people who don't like any fishy flavor.  Try it.  Oh.. we added a touch of white wine to the topping and the bottom of the pan while the fish broiled, and some garlic instead of celery salt.

text:
Easy and delicious.  Everyone (3 adults and 4 picky kids ages 3-11) gobbled it up.  Easy too!  I did omit the celery salt and used about 1 tsp. Old Bay.  I also added about 1/8 c. bread crumbs.  I wrapped them in individual foil packets and cooked on a med-hi grill for 12 minutes (no turning) and it turned out perfect.  About 30 minutes from start to serve.    I wanted a good recipe to wean the kids off fish sticks  and this one was just what I needed.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a top-notch recipe.  Even if you're not a big fish lover, like myself, you should definitely try this one.  The rich sauce made this fish spectacular.  Of course, you must love parmesan cheese or this won't work for you.  I used frozen tilapia fillets, defrosted them in the microwave, then cooked them according to the directions for a total of six minutes. Everything else was fixed according to the recipe. Remember that if you're only fixing two pieces of fish, you'll want to make a quarter of the sauce that the recipe calls for. The two pounds listed under the ingredients is equal to eight frozen fillets.

text:
I had this recipe printed out for 2 weeks. Every time my husband asked what was for dinner and I said "Broiled Tilapia Parmesean" he would beg me not to make it and end up buying pizza or something else to avoid it. 

Finally one evening I convinced him to give it a chance. (He's not big on fish if you haven't figured that out!) He ended up really liking it. When I make tilapia from now on I plan to use this recipe. 

My 8 year old and 5 year old both ate it, too.

Note: If you have a gas oven like I do, you may not exactly get that nice browned and broiled look. Don't worry - it still tastes good.

Went well with fresh steamed green beans.

The topping really added flavor.  I would add some salt or some kind of seasoning to the fish before broiling.  My husband and 9 year old daughter LOVED it and said they would absolutely eat it again.  As a fish hater, I thought it was good and would eat it again.

text:
Made this last night and it will become a staple in my home. I didn't have Celery Salt so I used Old Bay Seasoning instead. Also prior to broiling the fish I seasoned it with Adobo w/Cumin and fresh ground black pepper and as was suggested by another memeber broiled the darker side first - seasoned it the same on the other. I broiled it for 3 minutes on each side then 2.5 minutes once I added the parmesan mixture. Quick, easy, taste's good - nuff said!

text:
Yummy recipe! Neither my husband nor I are huge fish lovers. In fact, we tried Salmon a few weeks ago and didn't like it all, so I was really hesitant to try another fish. However, we both really enjoyed it, and I know we'll make it again.

I love how I have most everything on hand, and it's especially fast and easy if you have frozen tilapia on hand as well. I didn't have onion powder, and I only had celery seed, so I used garlic salt as a compromise...it still was yummy. I quartered the recipe and just make 2 fillets, and they turned out fine.

We served it with honey glazed carrots and crescent rolls.

text:
I tried it with Miracle Whip; I think mayonnaise would work better, as the Miracle Whip flavor dominates.  To the toppings, I recommend adding garlic powder, lemon pepper, bread crumbs.  Also, I found the topping to be too thick to spread easily over the fish, so I would also add a little milk for smoothness. I think I would also use 1/2 the broiling time instead of 1/3 at the end to get the cheese/bread crumb mixture crunchier.

Display Name:
McRae Family

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was excellent - restaurant quality.  It was very rich (butter and mayo), and I made several unanticipated modifications that really made this depart from the original (but still fabulous).  Once I committed myself to the recipe I realized 1) I didn't have Parmesan, and 2) I had some imitation crab I needed to use up.  So I got creative - I whipped up a mayo/butter/seasoning mixture based on the recipe (favored toward Cajun/Old Bay Seasoning, plus pepper, garlic, and celery seed) and mixed it in with the imitation crab.  I then layered sliced Havarti over the crab mixture over the tilapia, and convection baked.  I served with roasted cubed baby reds flavored with olive oil, rosemary and dill, and sprinkled with bleu cheese crumbles; plus a side of broccoli.  

What a fantastic meal!  I look forward to making this recipe as set forth (plus the bread crumbs - that will make a welcome addition to the texture), but it was a great foundation to modify when I realized I didn't have everything!

WOW!!! What can I say about this recipe that hasn't already been said?!?!? It was great....I mean, people licking their plates great! It was also very forgiving. I did not have any onion powder or celery salt, so I finely grated some fresh onion and celery and used regular salt...OUTSTANDING!!! You can't go wrong with this recipe. Kudos to Caroline C for sharing....This one's a keeper! WHOOOO HOOOO!!!

text:
Unbelievably easy and quick, with such outstanding flavour! This recipe took my kids off fish sticks for good. I have made this twice; once cooking it exactly as recipe states (perfection!) and once by placing the tilapia filets in a baking dish, spreading the parmesan coating on top, then baking at 350 for about 20 minutes and it was just as delicious. The broiled method is quicker, though, and gives the dish a beautiful golden colour. Serve this to all fish-haters, and they will be converted forever! The best, Phoebe! Thank-you!

text:
This was so good!  I've been wanting to try this recipe forever but was waiting until I found some good fresh tilapia.  I used light mayo and fresh basil.  When I broiled this, some of the topping melted off, but it could have been my fault because I prepared it about an hour before I needed it, and stuck it in the fridge.  It was still yummy though!  Make sure to grease your foil, because I didn't, and the delicate fish broke apart a little when I tried to flip it.  Served this with Oven Roasted Potatoes (from this site) and steamed broccoli.  This is a very good, easy recipe I will make often!

text:
What can I say that hasn't already been said about this recipe? It really is as good as everyone says. I used about 1 tsp of chopped fresh basil instead of dried, and garlic powder for celery salt (like many others), and it came out fantastic. I had about half a pound of tilapia and half a pound perch, so I just used both, and I actually thought the perch tasted even better...it practically melted in my mouth. I think I might melt the butter completely next time when making the sauce, as it seemed a bit "thick" and difficult to spread evenly over the filets. I also made a full recipe of sauce, even though I only had a pound of fish, and it left just enough to mix in excellently with some steamed rice as a side dish. The sauce is fantastic - you definitely won't mind having extra if you make more than the recommended amount.

I love this recipe! Great flavor, easy, and fast. text:
First let me say that we "loved" the sauce.  Very yummy.  I have never been a fan of broiled meat or fish but we went ahead and tried this receipe.  The sauce did not brown - it just ran off and down the sides of the fish and all wound up on the pan.  Also, the texture of the fish made us unsure as to whether it was fully cooked or not - so we ended up throwing it in the microwave to make sure it was cooked through.  I will make this again, but I think I would try breading the fish and baking and then broiling when the sauce is placed on last.  I'll let you know how it goes.

country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe last night and OMG it is EXCELLENT!!!! Very flavorful and quick to make. I made a few adjustments based off the reviews I read. I used only 1 tablespoon of the lemon juice, I didn't have any celery salt, so I used garlic powder instead. The other thing I did was to season my Tilapia with Old Bay seasoning and coat with olive oil spray as others suggested. Also, I used fresh Parmesan cheese for my cheese mixture. The fish was succulent and juicy and it only took a minute to melt the sauce on the top. I laid the fish on a bed of butter noodles with a side of mixed veggies and me and my boyfriend tore it to pieces. I will definitely use this recipe again and again!!!! THANKS Phoebe

I was in a hurry, and the "no marinating process" made it super quick and easy! Wonderful dish - 10 minutes from door to plate!  I have my routine down...mix up topping with whatever spices I have on hand, throw fish under broiler, throw cups of baby spinach in a pan with garlic and red pepper flakes for an equally quick sidedish, flip and slap the topping on the fish, and there's STILL time to pour myself a nice glass of wine.  Plus it's cheap, and makes the roommates come out of their rooms when they smell it!

text:
The flavor turned out great.  I added a few things like paprika and onion powder. I didn't have basil so I used oregano.  I also used a good amount of Old Bay. I followed another reviewer's suggestion and added a 1/2 cup bread crumbs.  It made the mixture really thick. Was it supposed to? Another reviewer said hers ended up swimming in butter....hmm.  My fish themselves were not dry, but the breading(?) was very dry. The flavor saved it and my family ate it, so I guess it's a win!

text:
This was delicious!  I am always tentative cooking fish but this was EASY!  I followed other suggestions and seasoned with Old Bay before broiling, and added the breadcrumbs to the topping.  I did 4 inches from top on HI broil, 2-1/2 minutes on the first side, 2 mins second side, 2 mins after topping.  WOW this was good.  Topping was crunchy,  not creamy though, maybe due to the added breadcrumbs, but we liked the contrasting texture.

I followed so many previous reviewers' advice and went with Shannon's advice, in addition to the original recipe. userID:
4281825
Display Name:
steve@worldwidewells.com
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tilapia is worse than carp.  For years we enjoyed this recipe, until we learned where the fish came from.  In fairness to the recipe, it is truly tasty.  A true testimony that if you cover any food with parmesan cheese it is delicious. 

If you investigate what farmed tilapia eat, you will step away from this vegetarian fish species. Most farmed tilapia come from a tank below a bunch of farmed chickens.  The chickens  in the water, the vegan tilapia are glad to eat the by-product.  They grow big enough on chicken excrement and then they are sent to your local grocery store.  Fun fact, you are eating a fish made of chicken .  Yum!  Cover a piece of dog  in enough parmesan cheese it might be edible.  But for our family, no thanks.  We prefer fish that eat other fish.  Farm raised tilapia is gross.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2019-01-11T23:35:49.743

text:
This was so delicious!  My husband and teenagers all loved it too.  Many compliments.  Based on other people's recommendations,  I cut the lemon in half and added some breadcrumbs to the topping. It came out flaky, crispy and savory. I did 2 minutes on each side and I think it would have been overdone if I did it any longer. Served it with spinach tortellini and a Caesar salad. I highly recommend it even if you don't like fish that much.

text:
I halved the recipe with minimal adjustments for taste and it was fantastic. I will definitely be making this again. 

1/4 cup Parmesan cheese 
1/8 cup butter, softened 
1.5 tablespoons mayonnaise 
1 tablespoons fresh lemon juice 
1/4 teaspoon dried basil 
1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper
1/4 teaspoon onion powder 
1/4 teaspoon paprika 
1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
1/4 teaspoon red pepper flakes
1/4 cup breadcrumbs
1 pounds tilapia fillets (although I used hake this time)
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2016-08-09T02:06:00.293
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
1780598
Display Name:
mukaikubo

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at broiling, and it turned out pretty good.  I used a large cod fillet, I was barely able to turn it once and didn't attempt a second turn, just put the sauce over the second side. I added more seasonings as other reviewers recommend: Old Bay, paprika, garlic powder, and crushed red pepper, and the flavor with all of this was very good. I did also add in some panko bread crumbs because the mixture was so runny it wouldn't have stayed on the fish. The fish was perfectly cooked and moist, I'll definitely do this again.

text:
The first time I made this I followed the recipe to a "tee". Hubby and 21yr old liked it. Second time I "tweeked " it. Used orange roughy instead of tilapia and sprinkled old bay on both sides before broiling. Also added a "pinch" of fresh parmigiana on top. Hubby and son raved! Now they want me to try this sauce on chicken.The orange roughy was a better fish, was firmer and not as watery as tilapia.

Display Name:
Teri

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this several times a month for years .  I always make the topping as written for a perfectly seasoned piece of fish and found it holds up with light mayo just as well as full fat.   I generally use frozen cod instead of tilapia  so I generally bake for about 15-20 minutes depending on the size and thickness of the filet then take it out to add the topping and switch the oven to broil.   Two minutes later, a delicious fish dinner for six or for one.  Truly a 30 minute easy peasy dinner .   Line your sheet pan with foil and the only dish you will have to wash is the bowl used to mix the cheese topping.

text:
I haven't tried this recipe with the celery salt, most of the time replacing it with seasoned salt. I've been making a healthier version of this with 1 1/2 tbsp Miracle Whip instead of mayo, and I've also added a nice twist! Add a bit more lemon to the bowl and don't add the parm cheese to the mixture. Cover the fish with the sauce after broiling and then cover the fish in parmesan cheese and Panko breadcrumbs!! Adds wonderful texture and a crispier fish!

text:
I used snapper , had that in the freezer as I don't eat tilapia or farmed raised fish, but other than that I kept to the recipe. I also used the foil which made the cleanup very easy, plus I kept the leftovers in it and just heated it back up in the foil pouch.  The only thing to remember is if you are using thicker filets than tilapia, like I did, make sure you have enough sauce made. The sauce is very tasty and so easy to make.

text:
Made this on a whim because I'm new to tilapia and had all the ingredients. It was great, and the topping is very tasty. Because of my current diet, I took out the butter altogether. I didn't feel like it needed it. 

A little suggestion if you like a little kick is to add Sriracha. It's my favorite combination with mayo and usually add it to anything that calls for a mayo-based topping. Just really good with fish too!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OK so I made this exact recipe but used it on Cod fish. My husband and I are not fans of Tilapia but love Cod and Haddock. We are always looking for something different to do with it other than the usual baking with bread crumb or seafood stuffing as a topping. So I greased a large glass baking dish, placed the Cod in the dish, covered tightly with tin foil and baked at 375 for approx. 20 minutes. I then uncovered the fish and spread the sauce on top of the fillets and broiled until done.

text:
Really great recipe, highly recommended.  This has become a regular in our house hold and is an easy way to impress guests without too much time and effort.  It is 4 instead of 5 starts because a few modifications are needed, especially, about half as much butter.  I don't like my fish dripping with butter, plus it makes the sauce runny.  Like other reviewers mentioned, adding bread crumbs is a big improvement and helps the sauce stay in place.  Some cayenne pepper also adds a bit of kick that we prefer.  Yummy recipe!

text:
I keep this one in my arsenal of recipes that I pull out regularly. It works well with almost any mild fish. I like to use flounder, as flounder doesn't have the "muddy" aftertaste that tilapia can have.  I absolutely love the flavors the topping imparts. I have used this a few times for my eight course meals as the fish course, using a half of a filet per person with fresh green beans.  A lot of times, I will pan fry the fish on top of the stove in a non-stick pan, then put the topping on and broil it. It works well that way, too. Everyone raves about the taste. If I could give it more stars I would.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my second time making this recipe. The first time I made it, I followed it to a T...4 stars (but that's probably only because I am not a fish person, and to me, it was still too fishy). I made it again for Christmas Eve, this time following some of Shannon's tips (see "most helpful" comment), and it was a hit! 5 stars, hands down best fish recipe I've made thus far. I followed the rest of the directions/broiling time exactly...just added 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 1/4 tsp crushed red pepper flakes, 1/2 tsp paprika, and 1/2 cup bread crumbs to the cheese mixture. (The bread crumbs is what really makes it a 5 star dish...the first time I omitted it and a lot of the cheese mixture melted off the tilapia). Not only did it keep the topping on the fish, but it also gave it a nice, crispy texture. So good that I've been asked to make it again on New Year's :-) Definitely going into seafood rotation.

This was excellent, and just as easy as was promised.  I will be making this again!  I followed the recipe exactly save for using celery seed instead of celery salt.  
--3rd time making this: I still don't own celery salt, so I've been subbing in celery flakes instead and I FORGOT the lemon juice entirely, yet it still tastes great. text:
I genuinely liked this fish recipe. It is very smooth and flavorful. It's tasty and pairs well..

The one thing I would be careful and suggest is to lightly coat the mixture on top to a fine layer. I made the mistake of plopping on a thick layer and the textures clashed. It being too soft with the soft mixture on top makes it too squishy if that makes sense!

text:
I have made this on several occasions and it is always enjoyed by all. I varied the recipe and used catfish, it was still wonderful, just had to broil longer.  I mixed the Kraft grated parm and some fresh shaved parm this last time and always season the fish with blackened seasoning and a little seasoning salt.  I added lemon pepper, cayenne and black pepper to the original mix.  This is one of our favorites! I have been broiling in a lined pan, I think I may try a broil pan so that the excess juice drains, especially with catfish.  The flavor is wonderful.

text:
Great basic recipe that appears to allow for lots of personal variation. I reduced the butter to 1 Tbsp and subbed plain Greek yogurt for the sour cream, also reduced the parm cheese to a generous 1/4 cup. I used celery seed instead of celery salt, and if you do that you may want to add a bit of salt. My tilapia fillets were small and I wish I'd reduced the cook time a bit, as they were a little dry. Not the fault of the submitter, of course. Thanks Phoebe!

userID:
12901585
Display Name:
Staci
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
64
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time last week & I am making it again tonight. I did make a few adjustments like others suggested. I did not use the celery salt because I didn't have any.I added 1/8 tsp of paprika & 1/8 tsp garlic powder plus extra black pepper, as well as another tablespoon of Parmesan cheese. I also put it in the broiler with the dark vein side facing up for about 3 minutes while still frozen then flipped it for another 3 minutes (the filet I used were smaller than normal). Added the topping and cooked about 5 mins or less. Turned out great, the hubby loved it as well! Super fast & delish...can't go wrong!
Review:
Rating:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out well, but I did make many adjustments as usual. I don't generally use measuring spoons, so my descriptions may be a little more general. I made 2 tilapia filets. I cut out the celery salt completely.  I added a couple dashes of paprika and garlic powder. I still added the lemon even though many reviewers cut this out. I used the olive oil mayo since it is lower in fat. I added much more pepper than what the recipe stated, but this should be done by your taste. I added some herb bread crumbs to the mixture and I also seasoned the fish on both sides before putting it in the broiler. I didn't notice any comments about the broiler, but I put it on low and just checked up on it after 2 minutes to see how cooked it was. This worked well for me.

text:
Fantastic! Based on some of the reviews, I cut the butter down to 2 TBSP and added some paprika. I also sprinkled a little salt, pepper & garlic powder on the fish before broiling. I think you could easily make it even healthier just by decreasing the amount of cheese mixture per fish - it's thick and flavorful, and I found a little goes a long way.

Watch the broiler carefully, this cooks FAST

userID:
11626143
Display Name:
teerudacille
isPro:

madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
How can something so easy be so good!? My dad, sister, and I have a cooking competition every two weeks to see who can make the best dinner, and this recipe won it for me! It is not a lie that this takes 15 minutes, and the 4 1/2 star review is not an exaggeration. It is important to note that you must mind your oven's variation on cooking times only for the sake of browner, more crispy mixture on top, not because the fish will not be cooked through. 
Also, I bought 3 tilapia filets, which I believe came to less than one pound (and the ingredients list says 2 pounds) but I still made the sauce like I was following the portion size on the recipe. I did not use the cheese-mayo-spice mixture lightly, either; I smothered it on those filets like they were some Waffle House hash browns. The sauce didn't overpower the fish; in fact, it was a perfect combination.
I served the fish with some sauteed mushrooms, and BOOM, victory was mine, and it is glorious! :D

This is a family favorite for us.  I have made a few adjustments that we really enjoy. text:
Made this last week and it went fast.  Really fast.  It was also easy, and used ingredients that are usually on hand in my kitchen.  I happened to have fresh basil so I substituted it for the dried and it added a very fresh taste to the dish.  It is also important to use a quality parm for this dish to taste its best, but it will still be excellent if you use something like Kraft.  I also seasoned the fillets with Slap Ya Mama seasoning blend before sliding them under the broiler.  So good!

Like others, I add my own touches to this. Hubby says he could eat this at least once a week, it's my go to white fish recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe!  We eat tilapia a lot and I'm always looking for new recipes.  This one is a keeper.  I used about 3/4 c. of unflavored Panko in the mixture as well as some sweet smoky paprika, dried parsley flakes and garlic paste.  I mixed it all ahead of time so the flavors would "get together".  The mayo doesn't seem to do anything for the taste, maybe it's just to help hold the mixture together.  Next time I may not use it.  There was plenty of topping for 2 pounds.  I will definitely make this again, my husband and son loved it as did I. Thanks to Phoebe for the recipe and the other contributors for their comments and suggestions.

country:

text:
This was wonderful!!!!! The only change I made was to add some panko bread crumbs, and I couldn't find my celery salt to save my life. With the Lenten Season here and the fact that my local store had Tilapia on sale for $2 a pound I bought quite a bit and and was looking for ways to cook it. Usually I make tacos. My husband would not try it because he "HATES" tilapia (He's never tried it LOL) but he does like snapper so I'm going to try it on snapper. I also think it would be great to add some small salad shrimp, or crab to the topping to make really fancy. I also think you could lower the fat using lowfat mayo and butter without taking away from the flavor. Love the fact that it takes all of 10 minutes to make a wonderful meal. Have the rice cooker set to start cooking automatically toss some vegis in the steamer and your done!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This time I broiled the fish 2 minutes at 500 degrees on the very top rack, turned it over and broiled another 2 minutes, added the topping and broiled until browned. It turned out perfectly.   2-1-2013 I'm still learning to broil, so the fact that I couldn't get the topping to brown is my fault, I'm sure. I followed directions and broiled the first side 3 minutes. Then I turned it over and broiled it for 2 more minutes. I added the topping and continued cooking for 3 minutes. I was afraid to keep broiling the fish for fear it would be tough, dry, and overcooked. It turned out delicious, even though it didn't get crusty brown. I'll definitely try this again.

Definitely adding this to my go-to recipe box.

Lulu

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/200958.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great Tilapia recipe. I changed some of the proportions of the ingredients, and took some suggestions from other reviewers. My biggest change was to reduce the butter and increase the mayo and cheese (used reduced fat mayo too). So for a serving of 8, my way came out to this: 8 Tilapia fillets, 1/2 cup reduced-fat mayo, 1 cup grated parmesan, 2 tb and 2 tsp butter (so that works out to 1 tbsp mayo, 2 tbsp parm, and 1 tsp butter per fillet). I kept the recommended seasonings (except I had no onion powder on hand), but took some suggestions and added 1/4 tsp garlic powder and 1/2 tsp Paprika. I also sprinkled the tops with a light coating of whole wheat breadcrumbs, and after broiling they came out with a nice, crispy crust on top of the cheesy layer. They different textures made it really nice.

- A touch less mayo

- NO onion powder, and NO celery salt
- fresh grated parmesan cheese I think made the dish!

text:
I love this recipe!  The only change I made was substitute cottage cheese for the mayo(I have a soy allergy...mayo has soybean oil in it). I mix the ingredients for the topping in my mini food processor so it's smooth and well blended. I also squeezed lemon juice over the fish and let it sit while I prepared the topping.  I think the people that had negative reviews needed to start with a fresh fillet. The tilapia that I get doesn't smell fishy even raw!

text:
This was surprisingly delicious. I was a bit skeptical at first because of the mayo, but it was delicious. My husband and my son both loved it. Some changes: I halved it, replaced celery salt with celery seed, added a bit more parmesan, and broiled without flipping it over for 4 minutes before adding the topping. It took roughly 2 minutes for the topping to brown and sizzle. And it was FAST! Cheap and easy--definitely making again.

I love that this dish is so quick and easy to make and that I didn't have to go out and buy special ingredients to do so. I thought it was quite tasty and would be happy to have it again, though it wasn't my all time favorite. My husband said it was just okay, but he's picky so who knows. The combo of ease of preparation, quick cooking time and good flavor means I will definitely be making this again!

None
text:
Love this and it's so easy.  In addition to the spices listed I add pepper flakes, garlic and paprika and drop the celery salt.  I use fat free mayo, a few Tbls of low fat butter, and add panko bread crumbs and sometimes Italian breadcumbs.  I actually increase the mayo since I'm adding the crumbs, it gives more to mix.  The cooking times are perfect.  I rub a little olive oil on the fish and start w/ the bottom side up so when you finish flipping, it's on the bottom.  Great recipe to invent more versions of it.  :)

text:
This is one of our favorite recipes. Over the past few servings of this, however, the recipe has evolved. We sprinkle the fish with garlic salt first. Then, I use 1 cup parm and 4 ounces of softened cream cheese, about 1 tablespoon lemon juice with zest and it's much richer. I also add 1-2 cloves of garlic. Save the cream cheese for less calories, but not as filling. This recipes topping amount usually isn't enough for us.  So glad to have found this! Thank you.

text:
Fantastic recipe and easy to make.  I did follow some other suggestions and added garlic powder and paprika, I also added some lemon zest.  I pared down on the recipe to make a single serving, and pan fried the tilapia in a small amount of olive oil after lightly dusting the filets in flour (it was just easier to do with a single serving).  After both sides were lightly browned, I topped the filets with the cheese sauce and let it melt over the tops.  Tasted fantastic and will definitely use this recipe again.

My husband and I love fish! However, our 7 year old and (2) 4 year olds do not. I baked this the other night and was amazed with the rich creamy parmesan flavor. I think this sauce is really rich so serve with something it will compliment like a broccoli with dill weed or some other fresh vegetable.

text:
LOVE this recipe!  We first tried this at my husband's brother and wife's house.  We had to have the recipe.  When I make it, I don't have celery salt or onion powder.  Instead, I'll sprinkle a few onion flakes and garlic powder (or sometimes I even omit the garlic powder).  I also do not use the black pepper.  This is so easy and so quick.  We both work full time, so I'll mix this up in the am or sometimes even over lunch break, put mixture in fridge and cook the fish when we get home.  Love it with Uncle Ben's 90 sec rice and a steamed veggie!  Enjoy!

region:

None
text:
Wonderful tasty meal. I had mashed potato as side. First of all, I scaled the recipe down to 2 servings. I love spicy food, so doubled the spices, used less butter, added 1/4 tsp of cayenne pepper, 1 teaspoon of black pepper, 1/2 tsp of garlic powder, 1/2 tsp of paprika and lots of crushed red pepper flakes. I marinated the fish in little bit of garlic powder, paprika, seasoning mixture (generic) and 2 teaspoons of buttermilk for 30 minutes (while the fish was defrosting). My roommate loved it. I will definitely make this again!!!!

text:
this is one of the best recipes for fish I have even tried.  Besides it being delicious it is so simple to make!

The only thing I have done different from the instructions is that I first coat the bottom of the pan before I lay the fish on it.  I found that just by covering the top, the fish was bland on the bottom.  Now it comes out perfect.

Thanks to Phoebe for sharing!

text:
Grill it! I've have made this several times using broiler and thought I would try it on grill. I put fish(brushed with veg oil) directly on grill using medium high heat for 2-3 min. flipped it for another 2 min. Put it on aluminum foil and topped with sauce. Put it back over fire and cover with lid til sauce melted. Delicious!!

This is an awesome recipe that is low calorie, low carb, AND extremely flavorful.  We use the Costco vacuum sealed frozen tilapia loins which are a little thicker, so broil 4 minutes on each side - then top with parmesan mixture and broil 2 more minutes.  The parmesan gets nicely golden brown and crispy just on top - very tasty!!

text:
Really good... Slightly strong on the lemon, I like halving it and letting people add more if they wish. A little bit salty as well, so be sure to use unsalted butter if you don't want a saltier fish. While good on tilapia, I think this would work fantastic on a stronger white fish such as halibut.
