photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I find that this is a very forgiving recipe, which is a good thing for me, since I tend to freestyle a lot of things because I hate going grocery shopping :)  The first time I made it, I didn't follow the directions very well, covering the bottom with half the parmesan/mayo mixture before broiling, and then flipping it over to cover the other side and broiling it.  It was delicious!

This last time, I didn't have lemon juice or the celery salt, so I substituted Old Bay and just went without on the lemon juice.  It made a really nice crispy thin crust on the outside of the fish.  I'm not sure if it would have done that, had I not overcooked it slightly, but either way - it was pretty good!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was easy to follow. It's a great starter recipe if you're learning how to cook fish.
We had no celery salt, so we didn't use it. Still tasted great. I cooked two fillets with sauce, and two with just some garlic and salt, just in case one of our sons didn't like the sauce.
This recipe was a smash hit with our five year olds, my husband, and a friend who joined us for dinner (and didn't mind trying a new recipe!).
This recipe also reheats well if done on low temperature.
The only things that I did differently (besides not having celery salt, thus, omitting it), was that I used less parmesan in the sauce, and put some on top after serving at the table. Yum!
Definitely a keeper! Thanks for sharing this recipe Phoebe!

I think this would have been good if I hadn't taken the advice of a reviewer and added half a cup of bread crumbs... it made the topping into a paste that was still soggy after being broiled :(  Also, I used frozen tilapia from wal-mart. Make sure you drain it really well as it thaws. Mine got really mushy.   End result: Mushy fish with a soggy paste on top. Yuck. =(

text:
Short answer - This recipe rocks! It is easy and quick, even for a novice like me. The flavors are wonderful and broiling the fish makes it wonderfully flakey and delicioso!   In case this helps anyone - I have not always been the biggest seafood fan, and am not a great chef. Due to health reasons I need to up my fish consumption (while lowering some other stuff I eat!) and tried this one. I have now made this twice in two weeks and may make it a weekly regular, everyone has loved it. First tmie I didn't even have all the proper ingredients, I subbed Nu-Salt substitute for the Celery salt and minced onion for onion powder and it still tasted very good. I think you could play around quite a bit with this recipe and it would be very forgiving. Wife said we could have this every night and she would be happy. ;-)

This was so so so good! Made this for a small group of people and they all loved it. As others suggested, I cut back to 2 tbsp. of mayo and I think that was perfect. userID:
4942492
Display Name:
thelorax726
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

23
favoritesCount:
78
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Another recipe to add to my favorites!  I made this a couple of weeks ago.  I used celery seed and onion flakes in stead of celery salt and onion powder (not too much of a stretch, but they were a bit chunky in the sauce) and I added paprika. After reading several reviews, I took the suggestion to halve the lemon juice as I am not a big fan of lots of lemon on fish.  I used a broiler pan and I had a hard time turning the tilapia and the fillets fell apart.  Even though they didn't present well, they still tasted great.  I went ahead and got the celery salt and onion powder at the grocery store this week and made it again. It made the sauce much smoother without the chunkier seeds and flakes and again I added paprika and halved the lemon juice. This time I baked them in a flat pan and the turning went much better.  They looked beautiful and tasted phenomenal with vegetable rice pilaf and broccoli.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-06-26T09:54:52.97

text:
My husband and I LOVED this dish! It was so fast, easy and absolutely delicious!  I was just saying to him how I'm really not enjoying fish anymore, but after this, I wouldn't mind having it every week. I didn't have the onion powder, but it didn't seem to matter.  It makes plenty of sauce and even the next day as left over's was great. I served it on a bed of wild rice. I will definitely be passing this recipe on to my friends and family!

This fish was amazing.  Even my 9 year old son asked for seconds.  I used light mayo and I Can't Believe It's Not Butter margarine and substituted regular salt for celery salt.  I also broiled the fish an extra 3-5 minutes to make sure it was cooked throughout.  It had a great cheesy flavor that was perfectly balanced with the delicate fish.  Very simple and delicious!

5/3/10 Made the recipe again and left out the celery salt -MUCH better. I resized the recipe for 2 servings, but used 2 TBS butter and !/4 C cheese -had some leftover but used most of the topping.  I'd give it 4 stars this time

text:
This is tasty, we have made it several times.  One caveat- it is a bit on the oily side, so this is one of those recipes that may benefit from using low-fat mayo.  Alas, I haven't tried it because I never have low-fat mayo on hand!  The dish is tangy and flavorful, and even my toddler like it!  I agree with another reviewer that you can take the dish and tweak it with good results- I often add a homemade "lawry's" style seasoning, and this improves the flavor and color.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I too altered the recipe. I seasoned the Tilapia with the Black Pepper (instead of including it in the mix,) Paprika, salt and Ground Cayenne Red Pepper. In the mix I added more Parmesan cheese (all freshly grated) and replaced the celery salt with garlic powder. I broiled the Tilapia at 525 degrees (4 filets) for a total of 6 minutes. 2, 2, and 2. My whole family (including my 3 and 5 yr olds) LOVED it! I paired it with steamed broccoli, cauliflower and cheese sauce. I will definitely make this Tilapia again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was amazing... and easy. I did the fish how it's recommended here, but also lightly pan fried some polenta as a base to place the fish on. Then I actually stacked everything. I swirled some of the sauce on the plate, then placed the polenta, then the tilapia... I added some sauteed asaparugus, baby portabella mushrooms, some fresh beans & sauteed shrimp. I lightly covered it with the sauce as well, and served it like that. I also added about a tblspoon of whipped cream cheese, then placed the whole sauce mix over low heat to help in mix together. It was so good that I actually had to write a review!

text:
If I ordered this at a restaurant I would be very pleased. It was tasty! I don't measure, so I probably used a little extra red pepper and I thought the little extra spice was nice. The only adjustments I made were using celery salt and celery seed (sprinkles of each - I only made 2 filets), adding a bit of bread crumbs, and tossing in some garlic powder because we love garlic. Oh, and I rubbed the fish with Old Bay. I think I'm going to use it next time as a shrimp topping. Yum!

Excellent recipe!  The majority of the flavor comes from the Parmesan, so the stronger the cheese the more potent the flavor.  I broiled .5 lb. of tilapia on high for 2 minutes, put on the cheese spread, then broiled for an additional 3 minutes.  The fish came out perfectly.

country:
None
text:
Wonderful!  I made this just as the recipe suggests, using some frozen tilapia fillets.  The sauce gave the tilapia a great flavor and even my six year old asked for seconds.  I cooked 2 minutes, flipped for 2 minutes and then cooked 2 more after adding the sauce.  Perfect.  Beware, though, that if you put your pan too close to your oven's heating element that popping butter can cause quite a bit of smoke.  (I had this maybe 3-4 inches from the top as suggested.)

text:
I added 1/4 teaspoon paprika, some garlic powder and about 1/3 cup bread crumbs to my mixture.  My fillets were thin, so there was no need to flip them. I broiled for about 2 minutes, then topped with my mixture and broiled until it was just browned.  With my additions, our family loved it and we'll definitely make this easy and FAST recipe again!

text:
This was pretty awesome.  I just threw 3 frozen filets in a baking dish.  I mixed a smaller batch of the sauce, but went heavy on the parmesan, butter, and lemon juice.  After baking the filets at 425 for 20 minutes, I spooned the sauce on top, cranked the oven to 500 and baked it for another 10 minutes.  Everyone loved it - even the picky 12 year old!

The only changes I made were to add 1/2 cup of bread crumbs, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, and 1/4 tsp paprika.  I heated up the leftovers for lunch today and they were just as good the second day.  Thanks for such a great recipe.

text:
I don't care for fish, but this was fabulous! Everyone in my family gobbled this down. I used the advise of others and seasoned the tilapia with old bay seasoning first and I also added garlic powder and paprika to the topping mix. The two people who don't even like fish felt that the topping was a bit overpowering, so we scraped some of it off. The rest who actually like fish said that it was terrific as is and don't change a thing. I would have thought that it would have been the other way around-lol. When I suggested that I might use less topping the next time, I was met with cries of "No way! It's perfect as it is!" My son-law is excited to try this recipe with other types of fish. I agree that this would be great on any fish. For me to enjoy this was incredible, but for my 10-year old daughter to like it was absolutely amazing! Thank you so very much for the perfect way to prepare fish that everyone can enjoy!

text:
The mayo topping in this recipe gives some much-needed flavor to an otherwise rather bland fish.  I had difficulty turning the fish over and felt it could have benefited from another minute or two of cooking.  However, my husband loved it, so I'll definitely be making this again.  Be sure to use shredded parmesan cheese rather than the finely grated -- the texture and better flavor will improve the taste.

text:
Mmmmm...this was a quick, easy dish that my husband and I loved.  The topping thinned out in the oven and browned and sizzled which made the dish look great.  The flavor kept us going back for more, I loved the tang!  On the advice of previous reviewers I substituted garlic powder for the celery salt.  I would have liked to have used fresh garlic and onion instead of powdered, but it would have burned under the broiler, so the powders ended up being the best.  The only drawback to this recipe is the amount of saturated fat in it.  Otherwise, lots of stars!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the best fish I've ever had hands down.  It has become a weekly staple meal.  Not only that, but it's also a very cheap supper.  Try lemon garlic steamed carrots and broccoli on the side to really finish the meal. The sauce and method of cooking is also delicious with ANY fish.  We've tried fresh rainbow trout, northern pike and walleye with this sauce.  All were delicious.  The pike tasting most like the tilapia, but only if caught in cold waters. 5/5 without question.  I VERY lightly rubbed the filets with Old Bay Seasoning before the first broil, 1 teaspoon for 3 filets.  It was just a subtle hint of spice that helps tone down the cheesiness a little bit.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
review change = 2ND ATTEMPT:  my first attempt was two stars due to the topping overwhelming the fish.  My second attempt I adjusted the recipe due to others reviews.  I cut the butter and lemon juice in half.  I seasoned the fish with Old Bay.  Instead of onion powder and celery salt and used a garlic/pepper salt in the topping. I placed foil on broiler pan and used pam (rather than greasing with butter).  My family loved it.  I had just enough topping for 5 talapia filets.  Next time I will try a shredded parmesan. I had a fresh grinded parmesan and it was very strong.  I think a mild shredded parmesan would make this better.  On my second attempt even with the strong parmesan my family LOVED this recipe.  My husband and son both had 2 filets each.

text:
WOW! So simple and so delicious.  I only cooked one pound (four fillets) of Tilapia so I halved the recipe and had just enough topping.  I also made the following changes: decreased the fat by using only one tbsp of light butter & light mayonnaise and sprinkled both sides with Old Bay seasoning, as others suggested.  The fresh, succulent taste completely livened up this otherwise dull fish.  I'll definitely make this one again!

The 1st time I followed it, it was excellent, the 2nd time I used no butter, dash of olive oil instead, fresh basil chopped, fresh chopped parsley, and mix of lemon & lime juice, and it was even better! 5 star all the way. Served it with wheat noodles tossed with veggies, fresh parm cheese, basil and parsley -- delicious!

text:
We love this recipe, as we love Tilapia!  I made the following adjustments and thus far we've stuck with the altered version.  I sub'd the celery salt w/celery seed, cut back to just under 1/4 cup butter, used real parm, freshly grated and added 1/4 tsp. adobe from the chipotle' can!  The family loves this version and it pairs well with anything!  It also makes a wonderful sammy w/cilantro mayo...YUM!!   :)..

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2009-08-01T18:16:12.027
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
1032812
Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:
False
followersCount:
97
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1009
favoritesCount:
2526
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really wish I could give this a higher rating, esp. w/ all the 5 * ratings on here.... Made this for my fiance & I 2night. While we both "liked" this, we didn't "like" it enough to make again (at least not w/o a few improvements). My fiance & I only tasted fish, no topping at all! As Carol Hammond did, I added paparika, red pepper flakes, Old Bay seasoning & garlic powder & used celery seed instead of celery salt. The only diff. is that I 1/2'd the amts. since I only had 1 lb. of tilapia avail. (I used sm. frozen (thawed) filets which only took a couple min. per side to cook thru). Oh, and I add. a little bit of panko bread crumbs just like LADYJAYPEE did for the mere sake of cleaning out my pantry. For fear of overcooking, the topping did not melt thoroughly. Extending the broiling time would have done the trick, but I didn't want to eat "rubbery" fish! For those of you who decide to give this a try, I have one suggest. - double the topping/spread or, if you 1/2 the recipe, make the ENTIRE amt. called for. Served w/ Basic Micro Risotto (Drasaid), a bagged Caesar salad & cheddar n' garlic biscuits, this was a nice meal. Thx. for sharing your idea, Phoebe :)

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
We really loved the texture and taste of this recipe. I made this recipe using haddock fillets as that is what I had on hand and it turned out great. I did not have any lemon juice and subbed in lemon pepper, left out black pepper, added seasoning salt in place of celery salt, and olive oil instead of butter. I did not flip the fish as my fillets were thin and not sure that this is necesary. Broiled on high only 3 minutes before spreading on the topping and back in oven for another 3 minutes. Perfect and delish! Thanks for sharing.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a keeper! So easy, so quick and so good. As other reviewers suggested, I sprinkled both sides of the tilapia with Old Bay seasoning. Loved the combination of flavors between the fish and the topping. It was even better the next day. I served the fish with homemade tartar sauce from this site,  baked potatoes and grilled asparagus. Marinate asparagus using a bottled italian dressing and sprinkle some garlic pepper blend on top (I let mine sit on the counter while I make the rest of the food I'm serving). Grill until desired tenderness. When you take it off the grill, put the hot asparagus in the same dish it marinated in. Toss again in the dressing and top with a touch of parmesan cheese while it's hot. And you've got yourself a mighty good meal!
Review:

text:
This was really good! Both me and my husband liked it. I did as others suggested and sprinkled the fish with Old Bay before broiling. I did substitute the mayonaise with sour cream, and substituted the onion powder with 1 finely minced green onion. I also substituted the celery salt with celery seed since that is what I had on hand. I added a shake each of garlic powder, paprika and tabasco sauce. Also sprinkled with bread crumbs after adding the cheese mixture prior to the final broil. This tilapia turned out very good! Thank you! =)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG...this was absolutely the best fish I have ever made. The only changes I made were to add 1/4 tsp garlic powder and I sprinkled the fish lightly with Old Bay seasoning before broiling as others suggested. I think next time I'll add paprika to the mixture.  The cooking time is crucial to avoid overcooking. Broil 2 minutes on first side, turn fish, 2 minutes second side, then remove and top with parmesan cheese mixture, then broil for 2-3 minutes more until the top is light golden brown. Perfect! Thank you so much Phoebe for submitting this wonderful recipe. Fantastic!

region:

country:
None
text:
Incredibly easy recipe!! I added a couple shakes of paprika & red pepper flakes, sprinkled some toasted bread crumbs on top of the filets before broiling the last time and omitted the lemon juice. All else was as stated in the recipe.  This was far too good for something so easy to make!!  Next time I plan on using lo-fat mayo & less butter to lower the calories. I can't imagine it affecting the flavor whatsoever.  I think I may use this for chicken too

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3788006.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I enjoyed this dish!  I took the advice of other reviewers and added bread crumbs, crushed red pepper, garlic and onion powder, and paprika to the cheese mixutre.  I didn't have any Old Bay seasoning so I also added some creole seasoning to the mixture.  I also didn't have any celery salt so I just skipped it.  I followed the recipe fairly closely but I didn't measure anything exactly.  I may have added too much mayo but my mixture turned into a paste, which I brushed onto the fish.  I also sprayed the tilapia with Pam before broiling the first 3 minutes.  I didn't turn the fish, only covered it with the cheese mixture and waited for it to brown.  This only took like 4 minutes tops for a total of no more than 10 minutes!  Great weekday meal and very healthy!  Thanks!

text:
Tilapia prepared this way is wonderful.  I made a few modifications to the recipe.  I doubled the sauce and seasoning recipe to make more topping.  Cooked it four min. on each side and 3 min. after the sauce.  You still get the great taste of the fish.  It was quick and easy.  My husband loved it!  He said it was like a gourmet restaurant.  This recipe will definitely be one of our must have's!  You should try it!

text:
Really tasty, even my wife who resists trying something new liked it. Try it without the celery salt & adding 1 cup of bread crumbs + 3 tablespoons olive oil or butter to cheese mayo topping, bulks it up & tones down the taste so it doesn't overpower the fish. Great fish dinner w/ rice at a budget cost.

I was able to make it even a little healthier by using Miracle Whip Lite instead of Mayo, also did not have celery salt, so used garlic salt instead, and it turned out great!  I would recommend this recipe as a great way to eat fish without so much the fishy taste.  All in all a good stand-by to make regularly!

text:
We don't eat much fish, but I wanted to try something that was a little outside of our box.  This was a fabulous recipe and soooo easy for a mom of twin toddlers! I used catfish fillets, and as some others had reccommended, I sprinkled the fish with old Bay.  I too found that the topping melted off of the fish and will try mixing a little panko bread crumbs with the cheese mixture next time to help anchor the cheesy deliciousness to the fish.  A keeper in our recipe box!

Claudia

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband loves this recipe just as printed, but I made some changes for ease of preparation.  I omit the onion powder and celery salt and use lemon pepper seasoning salt.  I also add 1/4 cup cracker crumbs.  I use frozen individually wrapped filets in a single layer (do not thaw), sprinkle with lemon juice, add topping and bake in 400 degree oven for 15 minutes, or until almost done.  Then I broil for 2-3 minutes to finish.  The cracker crumbs add a crispy texture to the topping.

country:

text:
Just finished eating - delicious!

It's a recipe that is easy to modify. I halfed the recipe and put over about 3/4 lbs of tilapia. I took some pointers and added enough panko breadcrumbs to add texture. I also added garlic powder, paprika & some cayenne pepper. I substituted mayo for french vanilla yogurt (because of a soy allergy) and it was fab! My 9yo son suggested a little sprinkle of red pepper. 

One thing I'll do differently next time is make sure the butter is softer and easier to spread. I'll definitely make this again.

text:
This dish is simply awesome. I do add bread crumbs for texture and season my fish first with onion powder, pepper and either seasoned salt, old bay, or cajun seasoning depending on what I feel like having that day. I use less mayo and sometimes omit the lemon juice when I don't have any on hand. I love this because it is quick and seriously good. Even my picky fiance will eat it occasionally (he's not a cheese or mayo fan). I made it once for my soon-to-be in-laws and they absolutely loved it. Its like a restaurant meal made cheap and quickly at home!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, so first I'll explain what I did then why I only gave it three stars. 1) I only made 1/2 lb of fish but prepared enough topping for 1 lb so there would be plenty. 2) I didn't measure the ingredients, just kind of threw them together until it looked good. 3) I didn't have onion powder or celery salt so I added about 1-1 1/2 tablespoons of finely chopped onion with a little salt. 4) I baked the tilapia on each side for about five minutes at 400 degrees, then put the topping on and broiled it for about 5 minutes, until nicely browned and bubbly. It looked and smelled amazing! We loved the taste of the topping, but we realized we don't really care for tilapia. My husband suggested I try the topping on cod next time, so I may do that. So that's why so few stars...we didn't care for the recipe as is, but hopefully I'll try it again with some other type of fish and it will be better. Thanks!

text:
Wow. This has become my go to fish recipe. So simple to prepare...you don't even need to measure really...just guesstimate and your good! I used Fage Total greek yogurt instead of mayo(I substitute that for just about everything calling for sour cream or mayo unless it is a cake recipe...good stuff!!). Also, I did not have celery salt so just used ground celery seed and that was great! I probably used a little bit more parmesan than called for and it was scrumptious! Family raved over it! Served with jasmine rice and grilled veggies with biscuits. Perfecto!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4498081.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a staple in our house. I always add about 1/2 cup of a mixture of Italian seasoned bread crumbs and panko to give it a little crunch. I never have celery salt, so I substitute garlic salt.

I cook the fish on an elevated baking rack in the oven at 350 degrees for about 15 minutes, then put the broiler on high (but don't put the fish near the broiler - leave it in the low-middle rack of the oven) and bake for another 3-5 minutes, or until it's golden and browned in spots. It gets nice and crispy on the edges and melts in your mouth!

text:
I absoloutely love this recipe! As a college student I am constantly trying to find something quick and easy. I came upon this recipe a few days ago after I picked up some tilapia at the grocery store and decided I needed a way to prepare it. I thought this looked tasty so I tried it.
I made a few of my own changes, however, because I was lacking some of the ingredients. I only used Mayo, butter, an Italian blend of cheeses (instead of just the parmesan), lemon juice, garlic salt, rosemary and tarragon. This recipe was quite a change from what I usely eat. (My mom is a very southern cook so I have decided I want to venture out.) 
I have already made this twice in the past few days. A great meal for one.. I actually just had some for lunch along with a ceasar salad and sauteed asparagus!

text:
I'm new here (and loving it I might add).  I read a lot of the reviews on this before making it and took the advice of the "pros".  I added extra spices and the bread crumbs.  The taste was extremely good.  I was worried that it wouldn't taste enough like fish for my husband...who is a major fish lover but it did.  However I think I might use less than 1/2 a cup of bread crumbs next time.  The topping was like a paste putting it on.  It tasted great but was really hard to spread on top and so I had to clump it on as to not tear the fish fillets.  All and all this will be a regular in this household.  Yum.

text:
This is great!  Add old bay seasoning to filets before broiling.  I added bread crumbs, paprika, garlic salt, celery seed, and red pepper flakes to the cheese mixture.  Tilapia is pretty much the only fish I like and I'm always looking for new recipes to try out because we eat it at least once a week...this is by far the best I've found so far!

text:
This is one of the easiest and best tasting ways to make tilapia.  The kids even love it.  We have been making this for years and have used it on other types of fish, halibut, flounder, barramundi, salmon, and we have even used it to broil shrimp (remove shells first and adjust broiling time). Great recipe.  Oops, forgot to mention we only use 1 TBS of lemon juice to cut down on the tanginess.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely WONDERFUL.  For the LOW CARBERS out there, this is perfect!  Some modifications:  I omitted lemon juice. I did sprinkle the fish first with some Old Bay.  I used celery seed instead of celery salt, added (as reviewer Shannon suggested) 1/2 tsp paprika, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, and just a pinch of crushed red pepper and a pinch of seasoned salt.  I like my coating a bit blackened, so I broiled it to a little bit of a dark glaze - not too much.  The fish was perfectly cooked and had a a bit of a crunch to it without using bread crumbs!  Served it with a side caesar salad and also rice for my husband. I used more then 1/2 of the recipe on 4 filets and it gave it a very even taste.  Not too fishy and not too cheesy!

text:
Flavorful, fast, low cal, cheap, and easy - an all around winner.  Yummy enough to serve company.  Fast and easy to make - can easily prep the sauce in advance and throw the fish under the broiler shortly before serving.  If you line the pan with tin foil brushed with olive oil - clean up is a snap.  Even with regular mayo and regular parmesan, still low in calories.  Tilapia and the other ingredients are pretty inexpensive (except for the cheese but you only use a little).  I didn't have celery salt - just used plain and didn't miss it one bit.  Otherwise followed directions to a T.

text:
LOVED this recipe!  Into the mayo I added bread crumb, cayenne pepper and I didn't have any fresh lemon juice so I just used the the bottled lemon juice and it gave it a nice tangy flavor.  I also omitted the butter as I thought it probably didn't need it with there already being fat from the mayo.  When broiling the fish before the mixture was put on I used old bay seasoning as others suggested and it really added a nice flavor.  I make a recipe very similar to this one using blue fish except I don't use the parmesan cheese.  

Thanks for sharing this recipe!

text:
We really liked this dish - I added Old Bay seasoning on both sides of the fish, as suggested, before broiling. I also added 1 1/2 T panko bread crumbs to the cheese mixture, and 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper. I didn't have celery salt, so i omitted it, and I didn't have dried basil so I used Italian seasoning instead. Also used lime juice instead of lemon juice. I served it with rice pilaf, but I think bread will be a better accompaniment. Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was not bad. I added a little garlic powder but otherwise followed the recipe exactly. It was a little tangier than I expected. I personally didn't think the topping tasted overwhelmingly of mayo, as I noticed most of the negative reviews said. It definitely overpowered the fish, though, so this would be a good way to prepare fish for someone who doesn't really like the taste of fish. I preferred it with less of the topping, so next time, I would either make less of the topping or not use all of the topping on the fish. The topping also didn't get as firm or as brown as I would have liked... I may experiment with adding the topping on immediately rather than cooking the fish first.

text:
Really simple and good:-)

I followed the other suggestions and sprinkled on Old Bay seasoning prior the first broil.
I kept the rest of the recipe same except I used reduced fat mayo and added some whole wheat bread crumbs to the topping mixture. I am glad I did because it gives it a little substance to otherwise a runny topping. It was very tasty, my 4 young boys loved it. 
Very kid friendly !!!

text:
INCREDIBLE!!!!!  We love the cheesy flavor on this fish.  My 4 yr old and 2 yr old sons ask for seconds every time I make it.  Also, I'm in a cooking co-op with 5 other friends.  I have made this meal twice because they like it so much.  It's super easy to freeze.  Just mix all of the ingredients together and store them in a freezer bag.  Once you thaw it, I just cut the corner off the bag and squeeze it over the tilapia fillets.  Seriously - it's delicious and an incredibly yummy way to serve fish to your family.  We make it again and again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sometimes it's tough to make a memorable tilapia dish, but this recipe is wonderful.  Wanting to reduce excess fat and calories (as well as sodium), I followed the advice of previous reviewers and skipped the butter; I also used reduced-fat mayo.  Additionally, I used celery seeds instead of celery salt--the cheese really does provide all the salt that's necessary.  Being a bread crumb fan I also sprinkled those on top.  The result:  a relatively low-cal, low-fat, and incredibly tasty tilapia dish!

This was great! Not only is the recipe great exactly as it's written, but it's so versatile. Change out the spices, or the cheese! I've added minced garlic and garlic powder on separate occasions. Plus, I've added a bit of roquefort to the mixture with the parmesan... so wonderful and rich! The first time I made this, I followed the recipe exactly, and my family ate it up! Even my 6 year old! So easy and quick!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/67880.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The best thing I would say about this recipe is that it is incredibly easy. So easy that even the most inexperienced cook could make it without having to ponder some of the instructions. The taste was all right, but not great. Our household tends to focus on wholesome, fresh tasting foods and this didn't really fit the bill (mayo + butter + cheese does NOT = healthy), but I figured I'd give it a shot since so many others liked it so much. I followed the recipe almost exactly - used celery salt instead of celery seed and low fat mayo instead of regular - but it tasted uninspired and unexciting. The mayo and cheese combination taste like Midwest comfort food (not my thing). Probably a great recipe to introduce fish to non-fish eaters, though, as tilapia is a naturally mild fish and the spread is enough to mask any lingering fishy taste. I'd give the ease of preparation 5 stars and the taste 3 stars, so 4 stars overall.

text:
I used Basa fillets (couldn't get Tilapia), freeze dried basil and freshly grated parmesan.  I got worried when the topping melted almost immediately upon spreading it on the fish, with quite a bit of it running off.  I broiled it until it was browned and bubbly.  It was very moist and flavorful, not at all overpowering like others stated.  I didn't pack the parmesan to measure it, so it was very light.  I will probably make this again, but I will reduce the butter to 2 tbsp, or omit it all together.

country:
None
text:
I made this tonight for my company and it was well received, although no one reached for seconds.  My only reason for giving it 4 and not 5 stars was that I found the topping to be too rich (I used full-fat mayo) and grease just pooled on my cookie pan (I don't have a broiler pan).  Next time, I think I'll try either using less mayo and butter or maybe use miracle whip.  Also, I did add a lot of additional seasonings per other reviewers advice: seasoned the fish with Old Bay, added about a 1/4 tsp of red pepper flakes, garlic powder (omitted onion powder), paprika, celery seed (omitted the celery salt) and 1/2 cup of Italian bread crumbs.  It definitely had a good flavor so I will try it again!

I may use this again but will need to tweek it to compliment the fish rather than cover the taste completely.  All though I'm glad it covered up the taste of Tilapia. 

I will definitely use a milder fish withought the "gamey" meat.

I also used low-fat mayo and added some bread crumbs, and I seasoned the fish with some salt, pepper and cayenne during its first broil. Definitely something I will be making again and adding to my regular recipes!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious and satisfying. I did not have any celery salt or basil yet it still turned out delicious. I did add some bread crumbs and garlic powder like others suggested, I may have added too many as I had to add some water to loosen up the paste for spreading without ripping the fish apart. I cooked this on tin foil on a broiler pan. Next time I will salt and pepper the fish prior to adding the topping as the few parts that did not have topping were flavorless. I served this with broccoli and cheese. Next time I make this I may experiment with Morton Nature's Seasons seasoning blend. It lists the following ingredients: salt, black pepper, sugar, spices, onion flavor, garlic flavor, parsley, and celery seeds. This seasoning seems to cover the bases without having to measure out individually.

text:
Everyone loved it. I will definately make this again. My son said it was the best fish he ever had. I made this a second time and realized as I was making it the 2nd time that I messed up the 1st time. My husband made the mayo mixture which means I know he did not measure correctly. So he did not put in enough cheese that was the 1st mistake. 2nd mistake was coating the fish with mayo mixture before it was cooked. With both of these mistakes the fish still turned out DELICIOUS!!! The 2nd time I made I followed the directions as it states and measured everything correctly and I still liked the fish the 1st time I made it. I think the next time I will use 1/4 cup of parmesean.

text:
This is my favorite broiled tilapia recipe!  I use lime juice, celery seed, and onion flakes as this is what I usually have in hand. I season the tilapia with cajun seasoning and add fresh garlic before broiling.  Finally, I add about 1/4 cup of seasoned breadcrumbs to mixture.  Cooking time is pretty accurate so follow closely.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good recipe and even better with the following additions... Juice of 1/2 a lemon, a few pats of butter and Old Bay seasoning, to taste on top the fish before baking it. Then decrease the lemon juice in the sauce to 1 Tablespoon and add 1 large (whisked) egg white to the sauce and the sauce will "Puff" up on the fish. The egg white makes the sauce look very "Elegant", sure to impress your guests.

text:
This is a great recipe, easy and tasty! I actually used Mahi as it's my favorite. This was my first time preparing fish and it turned out great! Hubby loved it and my 11 and 9 year olds ate it too. I doubled the "sauce" and used light mayo for last 3 T. and used garlic salt instead of celery. Turned out really well. (we do like things salty though, so take that into account) Another tip, the rice I served with it took longer than I realized, so I took the fish out and had to wait 15 minutes...just waited for the last step of putting on the sauce and finishing. Thanks for the wonderful recipe!

If I could give this more stars I would! This was one of the easiest and tastiest seafood recipes I have ever made!! I did double the sauce and added a little bit of minced garlic. I put the Tilapia in little foil boats to keep the sauce together. I also added a little more parmesan and topped with bread crumbs. The cooking time stated in this recipe was perfect!! This was so very wonderful! My only regret is that I did not try it sooner. Thanks for an easy and mouth watering recipe that I know we will make again and again!

country:
None
text:
This recipe was very tasty and so easy to make.  I'd been looking for a tilapia recipe so that I could finally bring myself to eat the fish and this did the trick.  My boyfriend thought it was great and even my brother (who does not eat tilapia) gave me a pat on the back.  I followed other reviewers suggestions and did not use the lemon juice, I only used 2 tablespoons of mayo.  I also added 1/2 teaspoon each of paprika, basil, and crushed red pepper flakes.  I did not have any celery salt on hand so I used a dash of garlic salt.  Also, I followed the cooking times exactly.  This was great and will make again...soon.

text:
Made this last night- LOVED IT!!!! Will definitely make again. This recipe was so EASY and so QUICK- I recommend prebroiling the oven, making the mixture & setting aside, then cooking your sides first before concentrating on the fish because it simply only takes a few minutes! I used seafood seasoning instead of the celery salt, added a dash of regular salt, and left out the onion powder for personal preference, and this turned out beautiful & delicous. Very happy with this one- it's a keeper!

"Best Fish dish I've had in I don't know how long!" said my husband after his 3rd helping! Finally, a five star recipe that lives up to the hype! I loved this fish...it's so quick, easy, and flavorful. I just wish it was more healthy. At least it will get me eating more fish.I made it with frozen basa basa filets, used an italian four cheese blend, light mayo, margarine instead of butter, celery seed instead of salt, and omitted the onion powder because I didn't have any. I was cooking for one 
so I just kind of eyeballed the measurements, so I think this is a pretty forgiving recipe. I've made it twice already!

text:
Oh my god this was the easiest and best fish I have ever made.  It literally took me all of 15 minutes to get it on the table. It made it even easier that I served it with some steamed broccoli.  The only way I differed from the recipe… I halved the fish but forgot to do the same for the topping, therefore it was very buttery.  
I didn’t use quite as much mayo as was called for and basically just squirted some lemon juice instead of measuring.
I didn’t really pay much attention to what spices it called for, I have been obsessed with garlic pepper lately, so of course that went on it.  I also put a little grated cheese on top before I stuck it in the oven.  Completely awesome, we will definitely be having this again!

There was not so much as a crumb left!  Thank you for a delicious recipe that had definitely become a new favorite!

text:
Gotta give this recipe 5 stars, it's just that good.  First dinner I made for my boyfriend, and he loved it.  :)  I'm a beginner cook, and in my opinion it's a simple dish.  Oh, and the sauce is SO delicious, you should make at least the portions described in the recipe, if not more.
In terms of modifications, I skipped the celery salt (didn't have any) and added bread crumbs to thicken the sauce as recommended by others.  Also followed broiling instructions provided by "Sheila in Texas" and fish came out fine.  Next time, I will try adding some cajun powder or cayenne pepper on the fish, just to experiment with adding some heat to the dish.
Paired the fish with Asparagus Cashew Rice Pilaf, which I also highly recommend!  Overall, it was a wonderful meal.  Will definitely make again.  :)

I love this recipe!! You can adjust it to whatever you have on hand. I preseasoned the fish filets w/ blackened redfish seasoning (which gave it a nice kick), substituted the original ingeredients w/ whole celery seed, garlic salt, and sprinkled panko breadcrumbs over the top. My family gobbled this down.  My only tip would be to carefully watch the time. It's FAST!!

Wonderful as the recipe calls for, although a bit runny, I'm certain that adding breadcrumbs would help a bit with the spreading.  I also did a big, huge modification by using shrimp I broiled with Old Bay Seasoning, I boiled up bow tie pasta, put it all in a bowl and made a double batch of the topping with too many breadcrumbs.  The topping melted down wonderfully in the pasta and the shrimp were just right.  It made a lovely crusty yummy along the top and we couldn't stop eating it.

text:
I really liked this recipe and will for sure be making it again. Even my picky three year-old really liked it and asked for seconds. The cheese topping had a wonderfully rich flavor that didn't over power the natural flavor of the fish but rather complimented it very well. My only problem with this recipe (as others have mentioned) is that the cheese topping mixture didn't stay put very well once broiled. Of what did stay on top of the fish, was very delectable.

text:
This was so awesome.  I made it last night.  My husband also does not like fish but he loved this.  My 10 year-old son loved it too.  We were going to grill them but it started raining.  I had already wrapped them in foil, so I went ahead and broiled them in foil for about 7 or 8 minutes with the topping already on.  Then I opened the foil and let them broil for a few more minutes.  I checked them and when they were flaky with a fork I knew they were ready. A really awesome recipe!

text:
I thought this dish was very tasty, but I did have a problem with it.  I put the fish on a broiler pan, and when I added the cheese/butter mixture it slid right off the fish, and into the bottom of the broiler pan!  I tried to get it back up onto the fish before it was totally lost...anyone have any tips?  The combination of the hot fish topped with the butter, which immediately began to melt, was not working for me.  I think my husband would've liked it better if it had been more cheesy.  If I make it again I may try some Jack cheese, as he is not a huge fan of Parmesan.

text:
Excellent! I did not have the onion or celery salt, so I used salted butter and dried onion flakes and two small cloves of fresh garlic.  A 1/2 of a fresh squeezed lemon added the perfect zing and the scent of the creamy mixture was intoxicating and the fish was delish!  I can see why non-fish eaters would like this recipe too!  This recipe is super fast to prepare and broil, but, it is definitely not a "healthy" fish recipe - however, being so yummy, we really won't care in the future!

I didn't change a thing on this recipe.  It was wonderful just like it is.  I plan to use the sauce in other ways - it would be delicious on chicken breasts!  Thank you, Phoebe:~)

I wanted to add a post script to this review:  I often send a sample of my newest recipes to a guy that works with my husband.  He called me after eating this and tried like he usually does to guess the ingredients.  He thought that since the sauce was kind of lumpy (because I used fresh grated parmeson) that perhaps the lumps were crabmeat.  He was very impressed when I shared how easy (and economical)this recipe actually was!

Wow!  I was impressed.  I didn't think it would turn out this well, as I don't even really like tilapia, but this was excellent!  Plus, it was super easy to make.  I made the recipe exactly as written.  The only thing I would change is to maybe broil the fish once it has the topping on it a little closer to the broiler so that it actually browns (I think ours was a bit too far away so it just got melty... we didn't want to overcook the fish).  But pretty much any fish would taste good in this recipe!

text:
My husband and I just love Talapia, and this recipe definately does it justice.  I did not have the celery salt, so I omitted that one ingredient.  (I have since tried it with the celery salt, but prefer the flavor without.)I have used key lime juice in place of lemon juice, and it adds an interesting twang to the meal. i have tried shaved parm from the chilled grocery section, but found this changed the texture too much, so i go back with the ground parm instead. This recipe has become my go to recipe when making tilapia.

text:
As usual, I was out of an ingredient right when I decide to try it. I had no Mayo. Being I do this so often, I just tried to think of what would be a good substitute. I used 1TBS Miracle Whip (light) + 1 TBS Deans French Onion Dip(fatFree) + 1TBS Sour Cream(lowFat). My hubby, who always makes a face at new things, absolutely LOVED the fish! So did I! It didn't actually leave a crunchy coating on it. It was more like a delicious melted cheese of a new sorts!  Fantastic!  Will make it again and again. So quick! So GOOD!!

text:
Let me start by saying - I DO NOT LIKE FISH!!  With that being said, this recipe was SUPERB. For any of you "fish haters" out there, this is the perfect recipe to help you get those "healthy" omega 3 fatty acids, and you will not have to suffer through it.  I am eating this recipe 2 or 3 times per week for health reasons, but the big bonus is that it tastes delicious. Serve it with some grilled asparagus (all from this site) and a side of sugar free jello with fruit in it, and you have an extremely healthy meal.  Thanks so much for the "only" fish recipe I have ever liked.

text:
This was a big hit with my husband and my 15 mo old.  I made a few minor modifications - less butter, less mayo, garlic salt instead of celery salt, and dried minced onions instead of onion powder.  I also topped each filet with a slice of tomato.  It was a little hard to spread the butter on the fish but I found if I let it sit on the warm fish for a minute, then it was easier to spread.

Very yummy, an absolute winner!  Great served on brown rice.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A very nice combination of ingredients to complement a pretty tasteless fish. I used onion JUICE instead of salt since there was quite a bit of sodium in the other ingredients and the flavor was much more subtle. I also used WHITE pepper to tone down so many heavy flavors (lemon juice, paremsan), plus our family does not like black pepper too well. I found that there was a bit too much of the sauce, or perhaps my fish were too thin. I will try cutting the recipe by an eighth next time, or perhaps making more fish. This recipe was so very good that everyone could have eaten more! Thanks!

text:
This is an awesome, easy recipe!  We used only 3 filets (1 pound)of tilapia , omitted the lemon juice (because we don't use the wegde usually given with seafood in restaurants), and used Old Bay instead of celery salt and garlic powder instead of onion powder.  For those health conscious nuts, we used light mayo and also just poured in some parkay no cal. no fat butter spray... can't tell the difference!  The tilapia tasted amazing!! We'll definitely be having this again and will serve it to friends and family.

As suggested by other reviewers, I doubled the sauce.  I melted the butter since it melts on contact with the hot fish anyhow; however, next time I will reduce the amount of butter.   I also had to make a few substitutions:  instead of onion powder and celery salt, I used onion salt and crushed celery seed.  Delicious!  My family doesn't like seafood, but my husband ate this recipe, and my kids really raved about it!

This was fantastic!  I broiled the fish with some lemon and butter and pepper to start.  I also substituted regular mayo for miracle whip.  My husband loved it.  I will make this again.

text:
Tasted great and was very easy... will definitely make this again.  The only thing I had trouble with was getting the cheesy coating "spread" onto the fish.  I ended up kind of spooning it on in globs, so it wasn't as pretty as maybe it should have been.  Also, if your tilapia fillets are thin, you should forgo trying to brown the topping... just broil until the cheese melts.
